Form No. 101
Sir:

I beg to refer to Departmental file No. 164-11-5 in connection with Mr. Agent Coleman's suggestion to provide a water supply for the Inkameep Indian Day School at Osoyoos I. R. No. 1, in the Okanagan Agency, at a cost of $385.00.

In this connection, I beg to say that Mr. Coleman advises that an Indian of the Reserve has successfully dug a well, and he thinks that as there is an improvised borer in the Reserve, it may provide a successful experiment to bore near the School at a cost of approximately fifteen dollars ($15.00) and that if water should be found available for a well the latter could be dug, and supplied with curb and pump at an additional cost of about $150.00, inclusive of labor, and the original proposal could then be abandoned.

I have advised Agent Coleman that I will support his suggestion and would recommend that he be authorized to have the boring done, and should this be successful, to place an item in his new Estimates for the sum of $150.00 as it is doubtful if funds will be available from General Vote and domestic systems cannot, if held at the Department, be used for domestic water supply but only for irrigation. If, therefore, the Department can approve the present spending of $15.00 for experimental boring, I would ask that authority be granted the Agent to have the work done.

Your obedient servant,

C. C. Perry.
Asst. Indian Commissioner for B. C.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, ONT.
Ottawa, July 30th, 1936.

Dear Sir,

The Department is in receipt of a letter from Assistant Commissioner Perry, with reference to your recommendation to spend an amount not exceeding $15.00 in an endeavour to ascertain if water can be obtained at the Inkameep Indian Day School. You may expend the above amount for the purpose mentioned.

Yours truly,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

James Coleman, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Vernon, B. C.

Form No. 101
Sir:

I beg to advise that the question of domestic water supply for the Indian Day School at Osoyoos I.R. No. 1 has been under discussion for some time, this school being entirely without water, the nearest spring being some distance from the school and the nearest creek about a mile distant, making it necessary for the teacher to carry his water in buckets. Incidentally there is no fire protection for the building and that it was not burned down by an adjacent bush fire about five years ago was due to the efforts of the teacher and Indians.

This situation was reported to the Department in 1935 and he recommended a pipe line be installed from the spring to the school, and the Department requested a report in their letter of June 6th, 1936 (File 164-11-5) and I advised them on June 12th, 1936 that the cost would amount to $335.00 for the pipe line and that sinking a well would be problematical owing to rock formation. The Department advised me on June 18th as follows:

"In this connection I have to say that the Department will have no funds this year to cover the cost of having this work carried out. A note has been made to provide the expenditure - approximately $335.00 - in our estimates for the next fiscal year. Before incurring any expenditure, however, the Department would require to be definitely assured that there would be an ample supply of water obtained from the spring and also that the pipe could be installed in a manner to prevent freezing in winter. It is noted that the result from the sinking of well would be problematical, owing to rock formation. You might furnish full information with your estimates for the next fiscal year."

and I included the cost in my estimates for 1936-37 as follows (page 6A):

| Item                  | Cost   |
|-----------------------|--------|
| 3000' of 1" pipe      | $300.00|
| Concrete for intake    | 5.00   |
| Fittings               | 5.00   |
| Indian labour         | 75.00  |
| **Total**             | **$335.00** |

Since that date an Indian who lived some distance below the school and had a well that was unsatisfactory has driven it somewhat deeper and installed a concrete curb and now has a satisfactory water supply. We have also rigged up a boring outfit in connection with settlement of young Indians on a new development adjacent to Inkameep Creek where it will be necessary to explore for domestic water; consequently I would recommend that a bore be made at the school to ascertain if a well is possible, the cost of which should not exceed about $15.00 for labour, and if water is secured a well be dug and a concrete pipe curb installed, together with the necessary pipe. The cost would depend on the depth to water but should not exceed $150.00 complete with curb, pump and labour.
If the $15.00 exploration in this direction does not produce results then it will be necessary to pipe from the spring at the original cost, viz $355.00, which together with the $15.00 for exploration would amount to $400.00. However, I believe there is reasonable prospect of well water. It is not anticipated that either project will require supervision other than can be given from this office as the pipe line system would be merely excavating and laying a pipe on grade below the frost line with a simple concrete box intake and screen. A well would of course be even more simple in regard to construction.

If this application is approved it would be appreciated if the matter could be taken in hand while the school is closed during the summer recess.

Your obedient servant,

(Jas. Coleman)
Indian Agent.

G. C. Perry, Esq.,
Assistant Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
P. O. Box 666,
Victoria, B. C.

Sir,

Replying to your letter of the 2nd ultimo advising that only $600.00 is available for repairs and improvements to the three Indian Day Schools in this Agency, out of the $1,285.00 requested, and asking my recommendations regarding the expenditure of this amount, I would advise that I consider the preservation of these buildings to be of first importance and would therefore recommend that the Okanagan Day School be repainted on the exterior and the Penticton Day School be painted both on the exterior and interior and that if funds permit that the interior of the Osoyoos Day School be attended to as it is very dingy. My estimates called for $300.00 for the Okanagan and Penticton Schools but this was based on quotations from the Tremco Surface Coating Co., and if it is necessary to secure the material from local paint merchants at retail prices, the cost of material would probably be considerably higher than anticipated. Paint (Tremco) for the Okanagan Day School would cost $20.00 plus freight—probably about $120.00. New ridgeboards for roof about $5.00 or a total of $125.00, and I anticipate I can arrange for labour for the balance.

Penticton School estimates by the Tremco Co. are $122.10 for material, plus freight—probably about $150.00—and about $10.00 for roof and ridgeboard repairs.

Possibly I can keep the labour costs within the balance of $110.00. If I can effect savings in labour costs I would require authority to purchase the small amount of paint necessary to redecorate the interior of the Osoyoos School which could possibly be done for $25.00.

Keeping the costs ($150.00 for the two schools) below my estimates (and redecorating the interior of the Osoyoos School in addition) will necessitate extremely economical procedure but as I personally own a power paint sprayer I believe it can be done and a superior job secured than under ordinary conditions and in this way be able to exercise full control of the quality of material used in the work, which is practically impossible in the ordinary way.

If this work can be authorized as outlined I would appreciate your advice by wire if possible in order that it can proceed so far as interior work is concerned during the holidays.

Your obedient servant,

(Jas. Coleman),
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

June 21, 1944.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver, B.C.

With reference to your letter No. 215-10-3111 of May 2nd ultimo in regard to repairs and furnishings at Inikameep Indian Day School as authorized by the Department, I now advise that I am still awaiting a quotation on the cost of repairs and an addition to the building from Messrs. Topping and Son, Oliver, to whom I have written and will call on again this week.

I, however, am forwarding herewith quotations of various local merchants on 1,000 feet of one inch galvanized pipe and it will be noted that the price quoted by P.C. Paul and Company, Penticton, of $16.50 per 100 feet, delivered at Oliver, is the lowest.

The length of pipe required to pipe water from the spring due East of the School is 1,000 feet approximately, and this could be installed as soon as authority is granted for the expenditure, subject, of course, to the co-operation of the Indians being obtained at this busy season.

However, the Band agreed at the meeting with Mr. Inspector Coleman on June 10th instant that the school should remain at its present site until such time as a new school could be built and agreed to co-operate in the installation of this pipe line from the spring, but with the present scarcity of labour and high wages being paid, it remains to be seen if they will keep their word and install this pipe.

I would request that I be authorized to pay the Indians a living allowance of $1.50 per day whilst working on the job and that a grant of $50.00 be made for this purpose.

In addition to the above, authority is requested for purchase of lumber required for the construction of an outlet box at the spring and for boxing in the stand-pipe at the school.

Hauling of the pipe and lumber from Oliver to the Reserve will cost about $5.00.

This installation will be proceeded with on receipt of the necessary authority.

(Alfred H. Barber)
Indian Agent.

As you are aware, there has been considerable discussion about the conditions at Inkameep Indian Day School in connection with which, amongst other things, the question of the supply of domestic water has arisen.

I asked Mr. Indian Agent Barber to obtain for me the cost of installing a domestic water supply from a spring in the locality of the school and I now enclose herewith his quotations which it will be noted are as follows:

Further to my letter of the 21st ultimo and with reference to your letter No. 215-10-3111 of May 2nd ultimo, in which you request that I obtain quotations for material and labour from local sources for the re-flooring, construction of a storm porch and an addition to Inkameep Indian Day School, I now forward herewith an estimate received from Topping & Son, contractors, Oliver, which quotes as follows:

Laying new floor in class-room........................................$78.00,

Extending building 12' on North end, using same exterior finish (siding), finished floors, Gyproc wall board inside and removing partition in living quarters.........................................................$66.50,

New porch over front door - about 6' square.
Same exterior finish, glass door and Gyproc wall board inside.........................................................$123.65.

The estimated cost of the porch and extension is much higher than I expected and it is my opinion, in view of the Department's intention to construct a new school as soon as possible after the war, that the cost is too high to warrant the alterations being done at this time. However, it is for the Department to decide as to that.

Topping and Son are the only builders and contractors in the Oliver district and they advise that they can not guarantee when they could do the work if it is authorized, owing to so much work and scarcity of labour, but would endeavour to do it before re-opening of the school.

I understand that the Widdowsons intend to return after the vacation if he does not receive the appointment at some college in the East which he appears to be hoping for. If he does return with his family, I do not see how the family or himself, wife and child could live in the accommodation as it is at present, without bringing forth more severe criticism from the element in the district that is so active in this regard, and therefore it would appear that the Department must either authorize the alterations to be carried out, or, if possible, obtain a single teacher who would be content to make the best of conditions as they are with such additional provision for his comfort as may be necessary.

If it is decided to proceed with the extension and alterations, I would urge that I be advised at as early a date as possible.

AGENT'S REPORT ON OKANAGAN AGENCY FOR MONTH OF NOVEMBER 1944.

INKAMEEP SCHOOL

This school has been improved by the re-flooring of the class room and the addition of a large bedroom, also necessary furniture. Also the water is now piped to the school door from the spring 1000 feet away. The school reopened on October 1st. However, it was closed from October 16th to 26th inclusive owing to the teacher, Mr. Widdowson, having to go to Vancouver where his son was ill. Many of the Indians of this reserve are still away and the attendance is poor, being an average of about seven pupils.

The teacher, in my opinion, is hardly suitable for teaching young Indian children, although no doubt very capable in his own line.

A. H. Barber,
Indian Agent.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 12th instant enclosing returns showing the attendance of Indian children at the Upper Trout Creek Public School for the quarters ending December 31st and March 31st, last, respectively.

In reply I beg to say that these would appear to be the first returns received of Indian children in attendance at this school and the Department has not entered into any agreement with the trustees for the payment of a tuition grant for these children. When forwarding these returns you should have given some further particulars regarding this matter.

In several cases in British Columbia the Department pays a tuition grant of $12.00 per capita per annum on the average attendance for the tuition of Indian children who attend white schools. This grant is paid quarterly on the receipt of returns of attendance made out on the proper forms supplied for that purpose.

The Department is prepared to pay at the above rate for all Indian children who may attend the white school at Upper Trout Creek and, if these terms of payment are satisfactory to the board of school trustees, a resolution of the board to that effect should be forwarded.

J. Robert Brown, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sumnerland, B.C.
You should, therefore, lay this matter before the school trustees and obtain a resolution from them accepting the above terms of payment and forward it to the Department, when, upon receipt of the same, the tuition grant due for the two above named quarters for which returns have been received will be sent. The name and address of the person to whom the cheques for the amount of the tuition grant due are to be made payable should be given.

Kindly give this matter your early attention.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. MOLAN

Ottawa, Sept. 24, 1917.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 10th instant in which you request that the Department will pay board and lodging, to the amount of $16 per month, for a destitute Indian orphan girl who is desirous of attending the public school at Trout Creek.

In reply I hast to say that it is considered that this girl could be sent to a residential school. Her age or religion is not stated, but, if she is between 7 and 15 years of age and is a Catholic, she might be sent to either the Kamloops or Kootenay Industrial School, and if a Protestant she might be sent to the Lytton Industrial, when it is ready to receive girl pupils, or to the Coqualeetza Industrial School.

You should make enquiry from the principal of one of these schools and endeavour to have her placed in one of these Residential schools, as the Department cannot provide the amount that would be required to pay for her board and lodging while attending a white school.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN

Sir,

From October 1916 to June 30, 1917 I taught in the school three Indian children of the name of Pierre, on the distinct understanding given me by the Indian agent (Mr. H.R. Brown) that for their tuition I should be paid direct, a fee of $1 per child per month.

I find that at least a part of this grant was paid to the trustees of the school who claim it as their grant, with the result that for my extra work with these children I receive no remuneration. As the law does not require me to teach these children, I naturally refuse to do so.
unless I am paid for my work. I should be greatly obliged if you would kindly let me know whether this grant is meant as a tuition fee or whether the trustees can use it for general purposes, i.e., buying cordwood etc. Your answer will decide the question.

The Indian Agent wrote I am sure he was out that he made a distinct promise that the fee was for tuition, I would be paid to me personally. Otherwise I would not have undertaken the education of these children.

I am

Sincerely,

John W. Harris
Teacher

Sir,

Replying to your letter of the 11th inst., File No. 500975-1, I beg to say that the Trout Creek School is a different school from the Upper Trout Creek School. The former being within the bounds of the Municipality of Summerland near the point where Trout Creek empties into Okanagan Lake, while the latter is situated, as the name implies, at Upper Trout Creek, four or five miles outside the limits of the Municipality.

The destitute Indian girl is the same girl who was desirous of continuing in attendance at the school when her grandfather moved to Shingle Creek. The grandfather refused to allow his grand-daughter to go to a residential school.

The cheque ought to be made out to Miss Stella Dynes who was the teacher of the school at the time.

OTTAWA, 13th October, 1903

The Deputy Superintendent General:-

With reference to the application for a school for the Penticton Indians I beg to say that this reserve is in the Kamloops-Okanagan Agency, which embraces nearly 4000 Indians and the only opportunity their children have of receiving an education is at the Roman Catholic Industrial school at Kamloops, which has provision for 50 pupils, and the new Church of England Industrial school near Lytton and the All Hallows Boarding school at Yale, also carried on by the Church of England. For about 650 children only 125 are thus provided for at these three schools.

There are no day schools on any of the reserves in this Agency and it would be next to impossible to provide day schools which would be of any service.

The Penticton Indians have one large reserve about 20 miles long by nearly 10 broad at the foot of Okanagan Lake, and two smaller reserves, one on the opposite side of the lake and the other some distance higher up. So you see that one day school would be of no general service to the Indians of this Band. There are only about 33 children of school age as shown by the last census.

Mr Agent Irwin in his last report says that these Indians, who are all Roman Catholics, are
industrious and many of them are well-to-do. They are located in the garden of British Columbia and as they are devoting considerable attention to fruit growing, their condition has very much improved within the last year or two.

These Indians should not be called Siwash which is a term of reproach, and they are temperate and moral, no instances of crime having been brought to the notice of the Department. They do not appear to be suffering from a lack of book-learning.
OTTAWA, 20th October, 1903

Sir,

In reply to that paragraph of your letter of the 1st instant in which you call the attention of the Right-Honorable, the Premier, to the need of education among the Indians of the Penticton reserve, I beg to say that the Department, to whom the matter was referred, regrets that it does not at present see its way clear to provide educational facilities for all the Indians of the Kamloops-Okanagan Agency. There are at now two industrial and one boarding school carried on in this Agency. Owing to the number of small reserves and the scattered locations of the Indians on the larger reserves in this Agency, it would be next to impossible to provide day schools which would be of any service.

The Penticton Indians are on a large reserve, about 20 miles long by 10 miles broad at the foot of Okanagan Lake with two smaller reserves, one on the opposite side of the Lake, and the other some distance higher up. You will see, therefore, that one day school would be of no general service to the Indians of this band, who have only about 33 children of school age, as shown by the last census.

Sir,

I beg to place before the Department the following facts with a view to an improvement being made in educational matters in the Okanagan Agency. There is but one small school in the Agency, at Osoyoos, which is unavailable for any other Reserves and during the past year I have carefully studied the question of education. In some cases I have succeeded in having Indian children attend the public schools which is undoubtedly the very best means of improving the Indian both in mind and body, but public schools are not often close enough to Reserves to be available, and Indians are not always accepted in them when they are. There appears to be strong objection on the part of Indian parents to allowing their children to attend Industrial Schools. They claim, not without reason, that the children are worked too hard and do not receive the benefit of their labour, and also that when they return to their parents, they are almost strangers and are restless and idle as soon as they are free from restraint. They also claim that they want their children at home out of school hours, which is also natural enough.

I have continually pointed out the necessity of education, and have won over many parents who, a year ago, bitterly opposed any mention of schools, and have even been requested to have teachers brought on the Reserves.
Two schools are immediately necessary, one on Okanagan Reserve No. 1 at or near Six Mile Creek and the other on Penticton Reserve near the Church and Council House. At each place there are at least forty and possibly fifty children of school age ready to attend. The two schools, of course, will only represent part of what will eventually become necessary. I have looked over the plans of various small schools built by the Provincial Government for country needs and find that a fifty pupil school with the teacher's rooms could be built for about $3,000., but presume the Department would have plans, etc. suitable for Reserves.

I respectfully request, therefore, that permission and definite instructions be given for the erection of these two schools at an early date.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

At Penticton, seating accommodation for 40 pupils will be sufficient and it will not be necessary to provide accommodation for a teacher.

I may say that the estimates for the current fiscal year provide the sum of $6,000 for a school on the Okanagan #1 Reserve, while the same amount for Penticton was disallowed. Day schools are urgently required on each of these Reserves, as there are no educational facilities provided for the children. I would suggest, if sufficient funds can be supplied, and the Deputy Minister approves, that plans be prepared for both these schools, and tenders called for their erection at the same time.

Memorandum:

Mr. Sutherland,

Will you please advise me what accommodation should be provided for in the day schools to be erected on the Penticton and Okanagan Indian reserves; also if it is the intention to provide a teacher's residence in connection with these schools.

Architect.
I beg to report that Mr. Inspector Megraw has advised me that only one school has been authorized for this Agency and will be commenced this summer, viz., on Okanagan Indian Reserve No. 1, and that the proposed Penticton School has been disallowed. This matter was the subject of several reports which I made last year and the decision is a disappointment. Several Penticton Indians who formerly opposed a school in every way have now changed their attitude completely and were looking forward to seeing their children educated. Two of them told me on my recent visit that if the school was not commenced soon, they were going to send their children to Omak, Wash., Indian School. Most of the educated Indians in the Southern part of this Agency attended United States Schools which is an unfortunate necessity as they return with a wrong perspective of Canadian affairs. The Penticton Public School, like most schools here, is overcrowded (although a new one is being built) so they cannot make room for Indian children.

There has been an objection to allowing the Penticton Reserve Council House to be used for educational purposes, but under the present unfortunate circumstances, I will approach the people again with a view to obtaining the Band's consent to this building being used for a school until one can be built.

I have tried to reduce expenditure in this Agency to the lowest amount hoping this would assist in having schools built, as I consider education is the greatest need of the Indians here. As a rule they are able to make a good living in spite of their lack of education, but this handicap should be removed from the next generation as competition will be keener when the country around the Reserves fills up with white settlers.

Although I do not wish to become importunate in this matter, its necessity in the interest of the Indians of this Agency is so obvious that it would be a neglect of duty if I did not make every effort to assist them, and I respectfully request that education in this Agency is given every possible assistance in future estimates. While
it is true that some Indian children attend Public Schools, this is most precarious as these schools are apt to close whenever the "white" attendance falls below a certain number as is expected at Westbank, or at Larkin where the school is closed on account of a Consolidation School being opened at Armstrong which will not admit Indian children. I only mention these as an example of the difficulties I am experiencing in having some of the children educated. At both these schools, which may not re-open after the summer vacation, there are nineteen children altogether who will have to leave school just as they have got well started in their studies and this, taken in conjunction with the latest information from Mr. Inspector Megraw, is most disappointing.

Sir,

I beg to report with reference to the above Indians that on Wednesday last, the 22nd inst., I met him in Penticton while on my way to Similkameen and he asked me to see taxi-driver for him about a disputed bill for car-hire, which I promised to do.

As I was leaving him I remembered having sent out some notices to Indians whose children were not attending school and told Timoyakin I had sent one to him. He asked me why I did that and I told him that the School had been opened over two years and the Chief had complained about several Indians who were refusing to send their children and wanted some action taken. He then threateningly said "If you try to send my children to school you will lose your life". I explained that this was a serious thing to say and told him to retract his statement. I asked him if he meant that he would kill me and advised him to be careful how he answered as he was liable to meet for intimidation. His only reply was "You will see", which was practically as much a threat as his other statements.

Considering the trouble I have had with this man, as the above quoted file numbers will show, I reluctantly laid an information against him and Magistrate Pope of Penticton sentenced him to three months imprisonment. It has always been my personal opinion that Timoyakin is not sane, but in the public good I do not think it advisable to allow him to intimidate in this way. The fact is well known since that Timoyakin was holding meetings of those who opposed the school and has threatened to throw him in the lake if he did not close the school on the Reserve.

Timoyakin has a bad record for intimidation in addition to five years in the penitentiary for stabbing. The Kootenay Power and Light Company employees had to have police protection when working through the Reserve on account of Timoyakin threatening as much the same situation arose when the Kettle Valley Railway branch line was built two years ago. Last year he bought the house on the floor of Penticton shooting ducks on each which is on the edge of the Reserve and tried to intimidate him into paying him a fine. On the man's refusal Timoyakin wrestled the gun away from him in a savage manner, severely bruising him. While the man was committing an offence (although he claimed he did not know it was Indian Reserve at that point) there was no occasion for Timoyakin's savagery.

You are possibly aware that he claims some kind of special protection on account of certain correspondence he has had with His Excellency the Governor General and also the Prime Minister, and he put up an ingenious defense after telling the Magistrate he wanted...
to be tried by the "highest court" as Mr. Pope has no jurisdiction over Indians. Fortunately Mr. Pope did not understand this although he told Timoyakin he was troublesome, contentious Indian. Mr. Pope told Timoyakin that he could be tried summarily or demanded at the County Court, but Mr. W.J. Kelly, acting for Timoyakin, advised me he is getting the conviction quashed because Mr. Pope did not say that in the letter event Timoyakin would be let out on bail. It will be unfortunate if he is able to quash this conviction as Timoyakin needs the lesson that he is not above the law. His influence among some of the Indians is bad indeed. I do not know whether you would consider it advisable to employ legal assistance to oppose Mr. Kelly's action, but if so it would be necessary to send these instructions. I think the records will show that I have been very lenient with this man, but cannot allow threats of this kind as it is not in the best interest of the Indians themselves to do so.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

[F.J.Ball]

Pentiction and Okanagan Day Schools were visited during this month, where progress is being maintained. The discipline is good in both schools and the children very keen. It is much regretted that there is still opposition to the schools among certain of the Bands, these being the troublemakers referred to above. They have no authority to tell the Bands to do anything but support them in this opposition by the authorities at Ottawa! As an example of the way they try to mislead the more ignorant Indians, two of them sent a letter to His Excellency the Governor General. The reply they received was merely an acknowledgement by the Governor General's Secretary, but was sent to them as "appointing Baptiste Chief, and boss of all the Indian lands", (Baptiste being one of the archtroublemakers). It can be easily understood how they misled some of the Indians, and I am continually being called upon to refute absurd statements which they make; but as soon as one ghost is laid away, scare up another; usually about half of the majority pay little attention to the agitators and these Indians try to lead them on, but the minority make a great deal of unpleasantness and noise out of all proportion to their numbers. However, the Idle Season is over and they will now settle down to work for another season and will not have so much spare time on their hands to employ in stirring up discontent.

With reference to your letter of 9th April, 1925 I beg to forward the following information which has been given me by Indians in this Agency.

Francois Timoyakin of the Penticton Reserve is again travelling through the Agency with another petition, which you will no doubt receive in due course. At first the petition was to prevent the R.C.M.P. Indian Agent and priest from having anything to do with the Reserve matters, but later a separate petition was sent in regarding the priest, apparently on the advice of certain self-appointed advisers.

I may say that the two Indians mentioned in your letter of 9th April, 1924 as having forwarded the petition against the school, have recently disagreed and Baptiste Chuchuhaskit laid an information before the magistrate at Penticton against Francois Timoyakin for the malicious publication of a warrant for the defendant addressed to him was taken from the Post Office by Francois Timoyakin, who refused to give it up saying "the information was not good for Chuchuhaskit to know". As a matter of fact the search warrant disclosed that this letter was merely an acknowledgment of a letter Chuchuhaskit had written to you and contained no other information. Timoyakin was brought before the magistrate at Penticton, who remanded the case. I think the police are charging him only with theft of cattle under the value of $10, and thus reduce the charge from a serious one to a minor offence. In this connection the R.C.M.P. report (copy of which I received) mentioned obtaining a search warrant and being assaulted by the Timoyakin family in executing it.

There have been a number of liquor cases on the Penticton Reserve recently, several suppliers being arrested by the R.C.M.P. there. In addition, they arrested a negro, several half-breeds and fifteen Indians for gambling. Indian women have complained to me that even their blankets have been lost to them by the Indians gambling and it was certainly time step were taken to try and stop it. But Timoyakin sees an opportunity here for obtaining signatures to another petition. They claimed in Court that the magistrate, police, Indian Agent, etc., have no jurisdiction over the Reserve and I notice in the R.C.M.P. report that the former Agent here, Mr. J.R.Brown, who lives near Penticton Reserve, appeared in Court to help these Indians evade the law and the police bear out what I have known for some time; that much of this petitioning and agitating is prompted by Mr. Brown.

As an instance of the danger of this attitude that the Indians are not subject to the law while on their Reserve I might mention that when an intoxicated Indian on the Saulteaux Reserve killed his wife about two years ago, the Indians actually held a meeting to discuss whether they should try the Indian in their own council house instead of notifying the police.

There was no suggestion of persecution by the police in taking action in the gambling case. Even some of the school children were among the number although not arrested. They had chosen a large root-cellar with scouts to give warning and the Chief stated he did not know where the gambling was done, although he knew it was going on. They all pleaded guilty except one and were fined $10.00 each. The ring-leader who had a lawyer to defend him was fined $25.00 and costs. Timoyakin's son and daughter were also fined $10.00 and costs, and any petition, to remove everyone who tries to prevent crime and lawlessness among them, will receive a certain amount of support at such a time.

I considered it advisable to forward these particulars so that you would have information in advance. I do not know the contents of this revised and inspired petition, but would welcome an investigation.

On April 23rd, 1925, F.J.C. Ball, Esq., Indian Agent, Okanagan Indian Agency, laid an Information and Complaint before Police Magistrate T.A. Pope, Penticton, B.C., charging Francois Timoyakin, an Indian residing on the Penticton Indian Reserve "unlawfully did intimidate by threat of using violence to F.J.C. Ball, Indian agent, with a view to compel him to abstain from doing something which he has a lawful right to do, viz., sending his children to school." Contrary to Section 510 (b) Criminal Code.

A Warrant in the First Instance to Apprehend the Defendant was issued by the Police Magistrate and served to the R.C.M.P. Police to execute. Under authority of Warrant Reg.No. 9904 Const. Bowden, placed Francois Timoyakin under arrest on the Penticton Indian Reserve at 11:30 am of the 23rd inst., and escorted him to the Penticton Municipal Lock-Up, at 2 pm. The Accused appeared before Police Magistrate T.A. Pope and entered a plea of NOT GUILTY to the charge. Evidence for the prosecution was given by F.J.C. Ball, Esq. Evidence for the Defence was given by the Accused and his Wife, Mrs. Helen Timoyakin. After hearing the evidence the Court found the Accused Guilty and sentenced him to Three Months H.I.S. at Oakalla Prison Farm. The Prisoner was escorted to Jail on the 25th instant by Reg.No. 9904 Const. Bowden, and receipt for prisoner, warrant of Commitment and prisoner's property will be forwarded in due course.

Case was prosecuted by Insp. P.L. Cadiz.

Under Section 501 (b) C.C., the Accused was given the option of selecting either Summary Trial or trial by Indictment - The Accused elected to be tried Summary.

Sir,—
Rex V. Lessard, Manuel, George & Timoyakin
Penticton Indian Day School

I beg to enclose herewith a cheque for $5.00 representing fines paid by the following Indians of the Penticton Band: George Lessard, Baptiste George, Julia Manuel, Mrs. Francois Timoyakin, under Section 10 (3) of the Indian Act on the 15th inst.

This represents the termination of the trouble on Penticton Reserve regarding the day school. For two years I have tried to induce every parent to send their children to school and have taken every opportunity of persuading them rather than taking drastic action. With many of them it was effective, but there is a determined section of the Band who have fought against the school from the first. They profess to believe that the Government claims four square miles of land round the school as compensation for the cost of building it. I am convinced that this is taught them by United States Indian women on Penticton Reserve who have married members of the Band. They point out various places in the State of Washington which they say were lost to the Indians in this manner. Penticton Reserve is so near the boundary it is difficult to persuade them that we have absolutely nothing to do with Indian affairs in Washington, but this sect who oppose the school also oppose everything which is done for the benefit of the Band. The leaders are Francois Timoyakin, and I regret to say, Chief Joseph Louie of the Lower Similkameen Indian Reserves. Chief Michele Jack of the Penticton Band has complained bitterly of this Chief's activities among the worst element on his Reserve and I am sending you a separate report on him.

On the 14th I held a meeting of the Band and explained the whole situation regarding the school and told those who had received summonses that they would be required to attend the Police Court next day to answer them. After the Chief, head-men and I had left the meeting, Chief Joseph called another meeting advising them to pay no attention to the summonses, and in consequence none appeared. Bench warrants were issued for their arrest and they were found by the police holding another meeting at which they had drawn up a petition requesting Chief Michele Jack removed as Chief. This will also be forwarded under separate cover.

The four mentioned were brought to the Court and charged before me under Section 10 (3) and all pleaded guilty, when they were each fined $2.50 and $2.50 police costs. Their spokesman said they would not pay fines.
or send their children to school so I committed them to jail for ten days in default. At this they immediately changed their minds and promptly paid up. I warned them that paying their fines did not relieve them from sending their children to school, as they were physically fit to do so having been examined by Dr. McGregor, and that any further failure to obey the law would result in the children being sent to Kamloops Industrial School. I say say that many of the children are anxious to attend but are prevented by their parents.

It was gratifying to hear the many expressions of approval of these actions from the Chief and other loyal Indians of the Penticton and other Bands. Many of them had driven from fifty to one hundred miles to be present and expressed their entire approval and hoped Chief Joseph Louie would be deposed and prevented from further interference with the Penticton Band.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

I beg to enclose herewith school returns for the three day schools in this Agency for the quarter ending September 30th. The returns for the Okanagan and Penticton Schools are very unsatisfactory as regards attendance. At Penticton this is deliberate as the Indians are refusing to attend as a protest against the survey of the cut-off which was made this Summer and they are awaiting the return of their Chief from Ottawa before sending their children to school. This attitude is not favoured by a number of the parents who, however, have been intimidated by the majority to conform with the actions of the malcontents. They have promised full support of the school on the Chief's return and I hope to have a more favourable report next time.

At the Okanagan School the cause of the poor attendance since the school reopened in September is on account of the Indians being absent in the orchards picking apples at which work the children are almost as capable as their parents and some of the families make very good wages. It would be advisable at the Okanagan School to make the holidays somewhat later than at present if this could be arranged, and I will take up this matter further.

At the small school in Osyopee the attendance is good. On this Reserve the Chief, who is quite progressive and industrious, gives every assistance possible to make his school a success, whereas at Penticton the Chief is opposed to education, which seems to show his unfitness for the rank he holds. The Indians admit that the children who have attended these schools have done remarkably well in the short time they have been in operation and I do not think these temporary difficulties will have any material effect upon the schools.

Sir,

Re Penticton School

I have the honour to report upon conditions on Penticton Indian Reserve in connection with school matters with a view to obtaining your advice and instructions.

The school question is inextricably entangled with other matters which I will endeavour to lay before you as fully as possible. The Penticton Band comprises some of the most progressive and some of the least progressive Indians in the Agency. The Chief, Michele Jack, is a weak vacillating person who has no authority among the Band and is mistrusted by both parties. When speaking to me he always professes to be in favour of the school but before the other Indians he seems to curry favour with the malcontents if they are in the majority, although he apparently signed the petition for the school (as per attached copy).

Not much harm would be done if those opposed to the school did not send their children to it, but the more serious aspect of the matter is that they are intimidating those who are sending their children, and these people being in the minority are now saying that unless all the children are forced to attend, they will of necessity be compelled to remove their children from the school.

In order to have a thorough airing of the whole trouble I held a meeting on the 13th instant, which was well attended by both factions. Previously I visited the school and found only nine pupils present instead of twenty-five or more who should have been present. I explained the necessity of the school and pointed out the provisions of the "Indian Act" compelling attendance so that they could thoroughly understand attendance at school was not a matter for them to decide among themselves. This precipitated trouble and some very strong speeches were made, including a request to depose the Chief immediately.

From the long harangues from six or seven of them I find that the principal reasons for their opposition are as follows:

1. That a few miles south of Penticton in the State of Washington, the reservations have been thrown open to settlement and the land sold to pay for the construction of schools and educational expenses of the Indian children, and the same would occur in Penticton.
2. That only a year or two after the Penticton school was built 14,060 of their Reserve is taken from them, supporting their contention as above.

3. That Indians do not need education and if all the children are educated they will become like white people and will eventually sell their reserve.

4. That they are opposed to accepting the money expended on the school and its maintenance as it will have to be repaid in some way or other, either by further confiscation of their land or taxation.

In addition to these points some of them went further and said the "Indian Act" was nothing to them, they were Indians and no law made by white people had any effect upon them. Dominick Paul said the Indians intended making their own laws, in future appointing their own chief and policemen and no white people or others would be allowed on the Reserve. There was considerable Bolshevistic talk also, which shows of course that many of these Indians are being badly advised. Baptiste Chuchuheskit is one of the most ignorant and most troublesome Indians I have ever met and he is the man they want for Chief. He said they intended to close the school, and prevent any children entering. I listened to them for several hours, and have never heard at any meeting so much stubborn ignorance and conceit.

The more progressive Indians and those in favour of the school were outnumbered and none had the courage to speak. I asked the Chief, as usual, to speak first, and he said it was no use for him to speak, they were all against the school.

If these Indians are allowed control of school matters it will have the worst possible effect, not only on Penticton Reserve but also on the other Reserves wherever schools are operating. Chief Baptiste George of Inkaneep Reserve (Seyoces) is watching the Penticton matter very closely, he is a strong supporter of the school on his reserve, but says he has a continual fight with some of his Band in consequence. As I left his Reserve after a meeting there on the 13th he asked me to tell him the result of my meeting the next day at Penticton and earnestly advised me to keep the school open at any cost. It is interesting to note that without a single exception, those Indians who oppose the school do not work their land, live under poor conditions and are usually dirty and unkempt in their homes and persons compared with those who support the school.

We appear to have arrived at a point where a decision will have to be made between closing the school or enforcing attendance. If the school is closed it will be a retrograde step which will take many years to overcome and may have far-reaching consequences, not only in this Agency but even further afield. It will mean peace on the Reserve for awhile at least, but not in the best interests of the Indians.

If the school is to be kept open, provision must be made to enforce attendance and protect those who are supporting it. This will necessitate the employment of a truant officer who will doubtless be strongly opposed in the execution of his duty. It will also be necessary...
to arrange to send the physically fit children to Kemloops Indian School who are prevented by their parents from attending the day school. The prosecution of an Indian and the imposition of a small fine under the "Indian Act" has no effect unless the parents realise that the next step is compulsory attendance either on the Reserve or at Kemloops. As a matter of fact they treat the fines with levity. The Indians have had a start given them among those already attending because a male teacher was appointed last September, but he has resigned and a female teacher will be recommended, commencing her duties about February 1st.

I have taken the liberty of reporting at length, perhaps some of the information being considered irrelevant. I was warned long ago not to attempt education in this Agency, one of the Indians going so far as to threaten my life, but unless a beginning is made I do not see how there can be any hope of making decent citizens of the Okanagan Indians.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

[F.J.O.Ball]
Indian Agent.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

There are about 28 children between the ages of 7 and 14 in our Reserve, all who should have the benefit of a school. Dear Sir,

We, the undersigned members of the Penticton Indian Reservation, desire to write to You regarding the question of sending our children to school. The Indian Agent says we must send them to the school provided. But we do not want too. Last year five of us were arrested, one sent to prison for three months, the other fined. Recently the Indian Agent was here, and said he would give us 10 days to obey, then after that he was going to have us arrested. He, the Indian Agent said that he should appoint a Constable, from among the Indians who obeyed the law, and that the others would have no say in the matter. We claim that all should have a voice in the matter. Will You let us know if the Indian Agent has the power to do that himself, whether You sent him to be the chief ruler over us. Before You discovered this Country...
We educated our children by the seven laws of nature, and would like to do the same now. We are ready to obey the laws of the country, but would like to be able to educate our children the way we think best.

We would like you to open the Court House in Ottawa so that we could come to you there in person and explain our case ourselves. We could do it far better than by writing.

Sir,

I have the honour to report, in reply to your letter of the 4th ultimo, that the Penticton Indian Day School matter came to a head on Tuesday, the 15th instant, Timoyakin being the principal actor, although it must be admitted there are three others, Dominick Paul, Dominick Buckley and Baptiste Chuchuhaskit, equally as bad as Timoyakin. The names of these four should be noted, as all trouble on Penticton Reserve is caused by one or all of them.

I was called to Penticton to meet the Grazing Commissioner on the 17th regarding co-operation in a clean up of wild horses on the ranges, and whilst discussing the matter with him received a message to the effect that the R.C.M.P. had been requested in trying to make some arrests on bench warrants of stipendiary Magistrate Pope of Penticton. I left immediately for the barracks and was present when the two constables made their report to the R.C.M.P. Inspector, one of them had been appointed trust officer and summonses had been issued to several of the Indians for non-attendance. No notice was taken of the summonses and the magistrate ordered arrests to be made. When the constables arrived on the Reserve they found about 40 of the malcontents, male and female gathered at Francisco Timoyakin's house. A warrant was handed to Timoyakin who at first said he would go and talk to the magistrate. Baptiste Chuchuhaskit, who seems to be considered a chief by these unruly members of the Band, told Timoyakin he must not go, they would stay on the Reserve. An attempt was then made to arrest Timoyakin, but the Indians gathered round the constables threateningly. Fortunately the two constables, Rivett-Jarnac and Woodcock, took a sensible view of the matter. They felt that the original offence was only a trivial one and they did not wish the Indians to commit a greater offence by obstructing or assaulting the police, so they returned to barracks to report.

The Inspector ordered the three constables to accompany him to the Reserve to make the arrests. I asked him to give me an opportunity to persuade the Indians not to get into trouble etc. I went out ahead of the police and found the Indians congregated in the Council House. Neither the Chief nor any of the decent law abiding Indians were present. Baptiste Chuchuhaskit met me and said the Indians were not going to allow white policemen on the Reserve and that the magistrate could not try Indians; they made their own laws and had their own Indian judges etc. I told him he was creating trouble for himself and the other Indians if he advised them in this way. Led by the four mentioned above they commenced milling around and shouting that they would not let the police arrest them. I pointed out that their own Chief was not present and they said he was a white man anyway because he wanted the school and was no Chief of theirs. By this time the police had arrived and the Inspector entered the room, he told them he had warrants for four of
them, that the charge was a trivial one involving only a $2.00 fine, but they had disobeyed the summons and he had come to take them. As they only shouted at him he called in the Constable and ordered them to make their arrests. Constable Rivett-Carnac touched Timoyakin on the shoulder as he sat on a form and told him he was under arrest, when Timoyakin immediately struck at the Constable who then took a hold of him and dragged him to his feet. This started a general fracas, men and women joining in, and it was impossible to see very much as I was busy keeping Chuchuheskit and Dominick Paul from actively taking part. The police handled the situation with restraint, even when one of them was dragged to the ground by Timoyakin and dozen men and women. They eventually got Timoyakin into their car although he fought every inch of the way. When they fell, he sustained a scalp wound by hitting the side of the form. Only three blows were struck by the police who were bleeding from scratches and had dislocated his thumb. During the melee Timoyakin's wife was knocked down; she is a veritable virago. The police then returned and took four or five of the more active Indians, including one young woman and returned to town. I stayed at the Council House and made those who remained there feel very much ashamed of themselves for their foolishness. Chuchuheskit and Dominick Paul refused to say anything and I could see that they all felt their position. I might say that during the melee no attempt whatever was made to offer the slightest violence to the Inspector or me.

The Indians were placed in jail and I asked the Medical Officer to accompany me when he examined them, but their injuries were not slight. By this time they all seemed in good humour. Next day they were brought before Stipendiary Magistrate Pope, charged with obstruction and were each fined $10.00 and costs except Timoyakin, who was considered the ring-leader his fine being $100.00 and costs. They were all defended by Mr. Woodward, Barrister of Penticton, but pleas of guilty were made.

The school cases were also tried and disposed of. Timoyakin had the day before this trouble taken his own child and four others to Nicola, a provincial government school about 30 miles from Penticton, and Mr. Pope dismissed the charge against him in consequence.

I found Mr. J.W.S. Logie of West Sunderland in close conference with some of these trouble-makers when the Indians were placed in custody, but one of them saw me and immediately stopped talking and went away. Logie is a clever man, an idealist and also the leading Communist in the district. I think the R.C.M.P. have certain information about him. It is unfortunate that some action cannot be taken against people of this kind. His theories are dangerous to Indians, although I believe he has no intention of causing actual trouble among them, but the fact that these malcontent Indians say they are going to run the Reserve without schools, or churches or agents or any other white people shows the result of his teachings even if he does not actually preach against religion, law and order.

Yesterday I went out to the Reserve and met the Indians who had paid their fines and returned home. They were all at their homes or on the road, I do not think they intended holding any meeting. I found trouble-makers present from all the other bands, William Madeleine of Salmon River, Edward Joe of Osoyoos and several others. The Chief claimed he was too sick to have been present at the council house.
when the trouble occurred and all the law abiding Indians said they were glad something had been done - they were being threatened continually for supporting the school. Many of them came to Penticton during the evening to express their satisfaction, and at one house where the father Harry Pete, had been afraid to send his children to school, the wife and daughters begged me, with tears in their eyes, to make Harry Pete send them back to school as they wanted to go. I have done this and these children are back again.

While these troublesome Indians make most noise, almost without exception they are the ones who do as little work as possible and make no use of their large holdings of land. Tinyakin is the exception, he is a fairly good worker. I hope some day he will have a change of heart and become a law-abiding and useful Indian.

As I have reported on before, the school trouble is really the result of the cut-off at Penticton Reserve and the most absurd statements are made by the Indians on every occasion to the effect that the rest of the Reserve will be sold to pay for the school; recently they say they have been told that four square miles around the school will be sold. At innumerable meetings I have tried to reassure them and they say it will be done without my knowledge or theirs either. The cut-off has made more trouble than it is worth. The 14,060 acres is almost worthless to anyone, white or Indian, except to raise a few head of stock. It will be many years before the feeling against it is eradicated. The past three days have been a rather trying experience, but I hope everything will now settle down peaceably. The school attendance is improving already and its strongest supporters are the pupils themselves, past and present.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

[F.J.O.Ball]
Indian Agent.

BRAVES FIGHT WITH MOUNTIES

Officers at Penticton Battle Way Out of Hall With Prisoner.

ACCUSED FINED

Special to The Province.

PENTICTON, March 17.—Acting out of the refusal of the Indians on the reserve to send their children to school, and following a free fight when the Indians refused to be arrested, Mounted Police attempted to serve them with warrants. Arrests ensued because of interfering with the police in the discharge of their duties. Among those arrested were Francois Timoyakin, George Lessard, Conrad Sam, John Smith, and William Grange.

The evidence shows Inspector R. L. Callicott of the R.C.M.P., and of Constables Carrock and Woodcock was to the effect that the Indians tried to arrest Timoyakin, the Indians refused to be arrested in a manner and they were unable to carry out their demands.

TOUGH DAY OUT.

Returning in the afternoon, escorted by Corporal O'Flynn and the Indians, Sergeant Woodcock and Carme attempted to arrest Timoyakin, when they were met by a crowd from twenty-five to thirty men and women. A free fight ensued, and the Indians tried to escape, but the officers had to battle their way to the schoolhouse. The backs, heads and faces were in evidence in the courthouse, here and there, on the streets and in the alleys. The officers' uniforms were also badly damaged.

The accused were fined $15 each and costs each.

GAUDE TROUBLE.

Timoyakin has been active among the Okanagan Indians on the Penticton reserve for several times past, and has caused much anxiety to Indian Agent Hall. The band is now being moved to another place where the government intends to take from them the land on which the school is built. Timoyakin wrote to Ottawa complaining of the treatment he received. There is no reason for their discontent, however, except that they are opposed to the fact that 14,000 acres of the reserve lands on the west side of Okanagan Lake have been taken from them some time ago, and they are afraid a similar course will be followed to take away the school built on the reserve by the government.

Woodcock proceeded to the Penticton Indian Reserve in order to effect the arrest, but so threatening was the attitude of the Indians, of whom some thirty or more were assembled to prevent arrest, that the Constables in question desisting the matter too serious to proceed with without further instructions reported to me.

On receipt of this information I proceeded to the Indian Reserve, with Mr. Ball, the Indian Agent, directing Reg. No. 7635, Cpl. O'Reilly, J.R., Reg. No. 9925, Const. Carmac, C.M., and Reg. No. 10109, Const. Woodcock, F., to follow.

I entered the Council House on the Reserve where the Indians were all congregated and, at Mr. Ball's request, went outside, allowing him an opportunity to address the Indians. While some time elapsed I entered, and seeing that Mr. Ball was making no headway, I told the Indians briefly and clearly that I had come out to arrest certain members of the Band, among which was the accused, for which I had warrants, etc., and that they would have to come. In the meantime Cpl. O'Reilly, Cpl. Carmac and Woodcock had arrived, I ordered them into the Council House and pointing out the accused ordered Cpl. Carmac and Woodcock to arrest, immediately on these Constables laying hands on the accused a general melee took place, some 25 to 30 men and women attacking the Police. The arrest was finally effected some 40 or 45 minutes later and the accused placed in Police car, together with 8 other prisoners and taken to the Penticton Municipal Lockup.

Cpl. O'Reilly laid Information and the accused appeared before T.A. Pope, Esq., Police Magistrate, Penticton, B.C., at 10 am on March 16th, 1927, under a charge, Section 169(a) Criminal Code "did wilfully obstruct a peace officer in the execution of his duty." He was represented by Counsel, W.A. Woodward, Barrister, Penticton, B.C., and entered a plea of Not Guilty to the charge. The evidence for the prosecution was given by myself, Constables Carmac and Woodcock, and Mr. Ball, Indian Agent, all of which went to show that not only did the accused obstruct and resist a Peace Officer in the execution of his duty, but that actually assault had taken place; each witness was more than corroborated. In the defense, Mr. Woodward, Barrister, admitted the charge but submitted that the accused was acting under misapprehension in the fact that he understood that the Government would deprive them of their land if they sent their children to school.
SCHOOL,

consequently he being an ignorant Indian, there was some colour of right for his action. He then put the accused on the witness stand and asked him to tell the Court his side or view. The accused entered into a long rambling account of how the Government had robbed them of their lands and also that they wanted to build their own school, etc., I recalled Mr. Ball, in rebuttal, showing that the accused and all Indians had been repeatedly informed to the contrary.

The Defence Counsel also objected to our authority in enforcing Section 10, Indian Act, by compelling children, as specified therein, to attend school; whereas we were specifically appointed as Truant Officers by the Supt. General of Indian Affairs, the objection was overruled after considerable wrangling and the accused was sentenced to pay a fine of $100.00 and costs, in default of payment 6 minimum months I.N.L.-Fine and costs paid.

I would say that respecting the objection of the Counsel for the Defence that it is unlikely the Police will be upheld in the future unless armed with appointment from the Supt. General of Indian Affairs, in compliance with Section 10 of The Indian Act.

I have requested this appointment in a letter to you of today's date. The urgency of this is apparent insofar as notwithstanding the action already taken by us to compel school attendance so far is not being complied with and I anticipate and perhaps more serious trouble.

No more force than was absolutely necessary was used in effecting these arrests and the restraint and good temper shown under very trying circumstances by Cpl. O'Reilly and Constables Garnes and Woodcock, especially the two Constables who suffered considerable abuse and injury, was wholly commendable and I desire to bring it to your notice.

BRAVES FIGHT WITH MOUNTIES

Officers at Penticton Battle Way Out of Hall With Prisoner.

ACCUSED FINED

PENTICTON, March 17—Arising out of the refusal of several Indians on the reservation to see their children to school, a following free fight when officers of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police attempted to serve them with warrants for arrest, charges of interfering with the police in the discharge of their duty were laid against Francis Timoyakin, George Leesard, Cosmos Sam, Julia Manuel, and Willis, Indians.

The evidence of Inspector R. L. Cadby, the Royal Canadian Constables Carman and Woodcock was to the effect that when the constables tried to enter the council hall again, the Indians gathered in a threatening manner and they were unable to carry out their duties.

FOUGHS WAY OUT.

Returning in the afternoon, the patrol by Inspector Cadby and the Indian agent, Woodcock and Carman attempted to arrest Timoyakin, when they were attacked by from twenty-five to thirty men and women. A free fight took place in the council hall and the Indians rushed out and way to the door with their prisoners. Cut heads and faces were in evidence in the combatants, but there was none of the severity of the melee. The officers' uniforms were also badly damaged.

The accused were each fined $5 each.

SECRETARY OF THE INTERIOR

GATEWAY TO CANADA

There has been a great deal of trouble among the Okanagan Indians on the Penticton reserve for some time past and has caused much anxiety to Indian Agent Hall who has been under the impression that the government intended to take away their land. Although the school was recently built, and Timoyakin wrote to Ottawa complaining of the proposed invasion. There was some reason for their discontent, however, since the Indians protest largely to the fact that 14,000 acres of the reserve lands on the west side of Okanagan Lake have been taken from them long ago, and they are afraid a similar course will be followed to pay for the school and other improvements by the government.
**INDIANS ATTACK MOUNTED POLICE**

Refused to Send Children to School—Warrants Issued For Arrest

PUT UP FIGHT

Men and Women Join in Melee—Several Injured—Lenient Sentences.

Arising out of the refusal of several Indians on the reserve to send their children to school and an effort on the part of the officers of the Royal Canadian Mounted police to serve them with warrants for arrest charges under section 169 of the Criminal Code of Canada of interfering with the police in the discharge of their duty were laid against Francois Timoyakin, George Lessard, Cosmus Sam, Julia Maracle and Willis Ignace. They were brought before Magistrate Pope in the local court Tuesday, the school cases being disposed of by a fine of $10 and line, principally white men, who do not understand the difference in the laws of the States and Canada, predict similar conditions here, the simple Indian believing.

Refusal to send their children to school is a protest against imagined injustice, and led to defiance of the law as exemplified in the recent attack on the Royal Canadian Mounted Police officers when they attempted to arrest the ringleader. A big responsibility rests on those who misrepresent facts to the aboriginal whose mental capacity cannot grasp the subtle insinuations of the peace disturber.

Magistrate Pope imposed fines of $10 each on each of the accused, but pointed out the law provides the penalty of $50 fine or imprisonment for two years. He took the case because of the wrong impression they held of the intentions of the government in connection with the reserve. Mr. Ball also pleaded for leniency for the accused, stating they had been influenced by others to resist arrest.

On behalf of Francois Timoyakin Mr. Woodcock claimed there was no assault made by his client except that he refused to be handcuffed. The evidence of Inspector Cadie of the R.C.M.P. and of Constables Carnac and Woodcock was to the effect that when the trouble began, three officers arrest on the morning of Tuesday, the Indians came in a threatening manner and they were obliged to carry out their duties. Returning in the afternoon, Mr. O'Reilly and the Indian agent, Mr. F. J. C. Ball, Woodcock and Carnac attempted to arrest the Indians when they were attacked by 25 to 30 men and women. The melee fight took place in the school hall and the officers fought their way to the door with their prisoners. Cut heads and faces were the evidence of the severity of the melee. The officers' uniforms were also badly damaged.

---

**INDIAN UNREST**

Among the causes for the present unrest of the Indians on the Penticton Reserve, as stated by Indian Agent Ball, is the untruthful assertions of white agitators that it is the intention of the government to confiscate the land on which the new school on the reserve was built.

As a matter of fact there is not the slightest ground for such a misstatement. Indians do not get the white man's angle where confiscation of property plays a part and the taking from the local reserve recently of 14,000 acres on the east side of the lake, has served to arouse suspicion of the further intentions of the government.

In the United States certain lands are taken and used for the education of Indian children, funds being raised by sale or rental of the estates appropriated for that purpose. In Canada no such methods exist. On the contrary the government provides the money for the education of the Indian. Agitators from across the line, principally white men, who do not understand the difference in the laws of the States and Canada, predict similar conditions here, the simple Indian believing.

Magistrate Pope concurred and Mr. F. J. C. Ball asked to take a place on the bench. Indian Agent F. J. C. Ball also gave assistance during the hearing and put out several points in connection with the grievances of the Indians. All the Indians except Timoyakin pleaded guilty to the charges of obstruction, but claimed they only did so when one of their women was being undressed.

Magistrate Pope imposed fines of $10 each on each of the accused, but pointed out the law provides the penalty of $50 fine or imprisonment for two years. He took the case because of the wrong impression they held of the intentions of the government in connection with the reserve. Mr. Ball also pleaded for leniency for the accused, stating they had been influenced by others to resist arrest.

Timoyakin has been active among the Okanagan Indians on the Penticton reserve for some time past and has caused much anxiety to Indian Agent Ball. Timoyakin wrote to Ottawa complaining of the supposed injustices. There seems to be some discontent, however, apart from the present trouble, in the fact that 14,000 acres of the reserve west of Okanagan lake were taken from them some time ago and will be sold. Similar courses will be followed to pay for the school built on the reserve by the government.

Mr. T. B. Williams, secretary of the Band Council, waited on the council with a request for a grant of $500. The matter was laid over for the completion of the estimates.
