Dear Mr. Stirling:

I am returning a letter of Mr. F. M. Buckland, of Kelowna, and I wish to state that there is another angle from which to view the recent unfortunate difficulty with a group of Penticton Indians who refuse to obey the law.

Certain malcontents, led by the Indians Francisco Timoyakin, Dominick Paul and Baptiste Cheshushasket, refuse to send their children to the Indian day school on the reserve. They believe, or pretend to believe, that any apparent activity will result in alienation of a part or all of their reserve. Time and time again, Mr. Indian Agent Ball of Vernon and others have patiently tried to correct this impression, but agitators have been able to keep a large number of the Band in a state of unrest. The result is that the non-progressives and least intelligent Indians distrust this department. I sometimes believe that Timoyakin and Cheshushasket are testing out their ability to get complete control of the reserve and to sever connections with Canadian government and institutions. I am very pleased to be able to say that there is also a strong sentiment of loyalty on the reserve, but it is the malcontents only that are heard in public meeting.

On January 15th, last, Mr. Indian Agent Ball called a meeting of the Indians to discuss the poor attendance at the day school. This meeting was well attended by both factions, i.e., the progressive, loyal Indians and the reactionary group. May I quote from Mr. Ball's letter of January 22nd:

"I explained the necessity of the school and pointed out the provisions of the Indian Act compelling attendance, so that they could thoroughly understand the school was not a matter for them to decide among themselves. This precipitated trouble and some very strong speeches were made." The question of alienation of their reserve was raised, and some went further "they said the Indian Act was nothing to them, they were Indians and no law made by white people had any effect upon them. Dominick Paul said the Indians intended making their own laws, in future appointing their own chief and policemen; and no white people or others would be allowed on the reserve."

Baptiste Cheshushasket is one of the most ignorant and most troublesome Indians I have ever met and he is the man they want for chief. He said they intended to close the school and prevent any children attending. I listened to them for several hours.

Grote Stirling, Esq., M. P.,
House of Commons,
Ottawa, Ont.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6406, file 835-1, part 2)
The more progressive Indians and those in favour of the school were outnumbered and none had the courage to speak.

If these Indians are allowed control of school matters, it will have the worst possible effect, not only on Penticton reserve, but also on the other reserves wherever schools are operated."

Mr. Ball pointed out in his letter that, with a single exception, the Indians who oppose the school do not work their land, live under poor conditions and are usually dirty and unkempt in their homes and persons. Mr. Ball concludes as follows: "We appear to have arrived at a point where a decision will have to be made between closing the school or enforcing attendance. If the school is closed, it will be a retrograde step which will take many years to overcome and may have far-reaching consequences, not only in this agency but even further afield. If the school is to be kept open, provision must be made to enforce attendance and protect those who are supporting it. This will necessitate the employment of a truant officer, who doubtless will be strongly opposed in the execution of his duty. I was warned long ago not to attempt education in this agency; one of the Indians going so far as to threaten my life; but, unless a beginning is made, I do not see how there can be any hope of making decent citizens of the Okanagan Indians."

I arranged with Commissioner Starnes, of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, for a member of the Penticton detachment to be detailed for special duty as truant officer for the Indian reserve. There were three steps leading up to the difficulty of the 15th ultimo. On March 6th, seven Indians were served notice by Constable F. Woodcock to send their children to school by the 14th of the month. One Indian - Harry Pete - complied. On the 14th, information was laid before Magistrate Pope and summons were issued for the other six. Five of these were served the same day. The sixth Indian - Old Philip - was away from the reserve. These summons required the Indians in question to appear at the Penticton Court at 10 A.M. on the morrow. Dominick Jack, only, appeared in court and the charge was withdrawn as his child was unwell. The other four - Joe Paul, Francois Timoyakin, George Lessard and Mrs. Anna Burt - disobeyed the summons, and at 12.30 noon, of the 15th, Constables Woodcock and Carnac proceeded to the Penticton Indian reserve for the purpose of making the arrests. Of course, they had secured warrants.

These two officers of the R.C.M.P. found the four Indians in question in a group of some thirty at the home of Timoyakin. They refused to come along, and, when the Constables attempted to arrest them, they were prevented by the Indians. In this connection, I should like to quote from the report of Mr. Inspector Cadis, of the R.C.M.P.: "So threatening was the attitude of the Indians,- of which some thirty or more were assembled to prevent arrest - that the Constables in question, deeming the matter too serious to proceed with without further instructions, reported to me."
Mr. Indian Agent Ball writes as follows: "When the Constables arrived on the reserve, they found about forty of the malevolent, male and female, gathered at Francois Timoyakin's house. A warrant was handed to Timoyakin, who at first said he would go and talk to the Magistrate. Baptiste Chuchuhaskit, who seems to be considered a chief by these unruly members of the Band, told Timoyakin he must not go - they would stay on the reserve. An attempt was then made to arrest Timoyakin, but the Indians gathered round the Constables, threateningly. Fortunately, the two Constables - Carnac and Woodcock - took a sensible view of the matter. They felt that the original offence was only a trivial one and they did not wish the Indians to commit a greater offence by obstructing or assaulting the Police, so they returned to barracks to report."

Inspector Gadin and three constables, accompanied by Mr. Ball, the Indian Agent, proceeded to the reserve to make the arrests. I shall now quote from Inspector Gadin's report: "I entered the Council House on the Reserve, where the Indians were all congregated, and, at Mr. Ball's request, went outside allowing him an opportunity to address the Indians. After some time elapsed, I entered, and, seeing that Mr. Ball was making no headway, I told the Indians briefly and clearly that I had come out to arrest certain members of the Band, among which was the accused, for which I had warrants, etc., and that they would have to come. In the meantime, Cpl. O'Reilly, Cst. Carnac and Woodcock had arrived. I ordered them into the Council House, and, pointing out the accused, ordered Csts. Carnac and Woodcock to arrest. Immediately on these Constables laying hands on the accused, a general melee took place, some 25 to 30 men and women attacking the Police. The arrest was finally effected some 40 or 45 minutes later and the accused placed in police car, together with 5 other prisoners, and taken to the Penticton Municipal Lockup."

Mr. Ball reports in part as follows: "The Inspector ordered the three Constables to accompany him to the reserve to make the arrests. I asked him to give me an opportunity to persuade the Indians not to get into trouble. So I went out ahead of the Police and found the Indians congregated in the Council House. Neither the Chief nor any of the law-abiding Indians were present. Baptiste Chuchuhaskit met me and said the Indians were not going to allow white policemen on the Reserve and that the Band would not try Indians; they made their own laws and had their own Indian judges, etc. I told him he was creating trouble for himself and the other Indians if he advised them in this way. The Indians commenced milling around and shouting that they would not let the Police arrest them. I pointed out that their own Chief was not present and they said he was a white man anyway because he wanted the school and was no Chief of theirs. By this time the Police had arrived and the Inspector entered the room. He told them he had warrants for four of them, that the charge was a trivial one involving only a $2.00 fine, but they had disobeyed the summons and he had orders to take them. They all shouted at him, he called in the Constables and ordered them to make their arrests. Constable Rivett-Carnac touched Timoyakin on the shoulder as he sat on a form and told him he was under arrest, when Timoyakin immediately struck at the Constable, who then took a hold of him and dragged him to...
his feet. This started a general fracas, men and women joining in, and it was impossible to see very much as I was busy keeping Cheshushasket and Cominick Paul from actively taking part. The police handled the situation with restraint, even when one of them was dragged to the ground by Timoyakin and a dozen men and women. They eventually got Timoyakin into their car, although he fought every inch of the way, when they fell, he sustained a badly-sewed by hitting the edge of the form. Only three blows were struck by the police who were bleeding from scratches and one had dislocated his thumb. During the melee Timoyakin's wife was knocked down; she is a veritable virago. The police then returned and took four or five of the most active Indians, including one young woman and returned to town. I stayed at the Council House and made those who remained there feel very much ashamed of themselves for their foolishness. Cheshushasket and Cominick Paul refused to say anything and I could see that they all felt their position. I might say that during the melee no attempt whatever was made to offer the slightest violence to the Inspector or me. The Indians were placed in jail and I asked the Medical Officer to accompany me when he examined them, but their injuries were only slight. By this time they all seemed in good humour."

This story is somewhat different to that related to Mr. Buckland. The Indians, and not the police, were the aggressors in the free-for-all. Mr. Hall has on many occasions with great patience explained to the Indians the reasons for the school law. Mr. Buckland writes: "It is generally stated that, had these Indians been served with court process in the usual way, they would undoubtedly have appeared in Court to answer such charges as might be preferred against them." In reply to this, I wish to point out that the four Indians whom the police set out to arrest on the afternoon of the 15th of March had been served with notice to send their children to school on the 9th of the month, they had failed to comply by the 14th and summons were then served. These four failed to appear in Court on the morning of the 15th and the warrants were then issued. At noon of the 15th, they had a further opportunity to proceed to Court quietly, when the two policemen presented themselves on the reserve. I am inclined to believe that these Indians were treated with patience and I have already congratulated the Commissioner of the R. C. M. P. on the restraint shown by the members of the Penticton detachment.

Referring to Mr. Buckland's remarks concerning Mr. Hall, may I state that on the 17th of March he went out to the reserve and had the assurance of all the law-abiding Indians that they were glad something had been done as they were being threatened continually for supporting the school. Further, quoting from his report: "Many of them came to Penticton during the evening to express their satisfaction and at one house, where the father, Harry Pete, had been afraid to send his children to school, the wife and daughters begged me with tears in their eyes to make Harry Pete send them back to school as they wanted to go. I have done this and these children are back again. . . . . . . . . . . . . The past
three days have been a rather trying experience, but I hope everything will now settle down peaceably. The school attendance is improved already and its strongest supporters are the pupils themselves, past and present."

The Magistrate, who was no doubt influenced by Mr. Ball's recommendations, took a very lenient view of the matter and did not send anyone to jail. Tinoaykin, who is considered one of the mischief-makers, was fined $5 and costs for failing to send children to school and $100 and costs for resisting and obstructing. On the same charges, Lousard was fined $5 and costs and $10 and costs, respectively. One other of the original seven charged with failing to send their children was fined $3 and costs. Three Indians were arrested in connection with the obstruction of the Police. Two were fined $10 and costs and the third, costs only.

In Mr. Buckland's letter, there is mention of an alienation of land from the reserve for school purposes. He writes of two miles square, which comprises the Indian settlement on the reserve. May I state that the land on which the school is situated is still Indian reserve and at the outside only one acre is used for school purposes.

Baptiste Cheshuhaskit's report on the affair disagrees so materially with the official reports of the Police and the Indian Agent, that I do not see any merit in replying to it.

I am very hopeful that this whole affair, while most unfortunate and regrettable, will have a very salutary effect on the malcontents of the reserve. The Department must hold the ground that it has gained against the reactionary element, or the progress of the Okanagan Indian groups will receive a serious setback. The patience of Mr. Ball, the restraint of the Police and the decisions of the Magistrate all go to show that our attitude has been one of forbearance.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

MEMORANDUM

INDIANS FINED FOR OBSTRUCTING POLICE

Penticton Case Arose Out of Recent Fiasco With Officers in Council Chamber.

PENTICTON, April 11.—Arising out of the fracas on the Indian reserve here in March, Cho-Cho-estak and Dominic Buckley were arrested and charged before Magistrate Pope with obstructing the police in the discharge of their duty. Cho-Cho-estak barricaded himself in his cabin and the Mounted Police attempted to arrest five of their number who refused to come out. Orders to the new building recently built by the government on the reserve by Mr. Buckley held the door of an automobile when Constantine Buckock and Carmie tried to get the men into custody. As a result the men they had seized at that time were not released until late in the day, and only after a severe fight between the Indians and the police, several of whom received injury. About thirty natives attacked the Mounted Police, five of whom had to quit their way and prisoners from the council chamber where the Indians were held.

In imposing a fine of $100 and costs on each of the men Magistrate Pope said it was evident there had been evil influence growing among the Indians for some time past and that behind the prisoners were the ring-leaders in an attempt to defy the law. In lieu of payment the fine the Indians will be committed to prison for six months.

The school at Penticton still exists on the reserve, the Indians refusing to send their children to the government school, they claim being under the impression intended to take more of their land to pay for its erection.

I have the honour to refer to your letter of the 6th ultimo enclosing notice to parents etc., and beg to draw your attention to a legal technicality which has been taken advantage of by Mr. Woodward, a lawyer in Penticton, in cases handled by the truant officer against Indians for non-attendance.

In Section 10 (1) of the "Indian Act" as well as in the notice it states that every Indian child shall attend such school "as may be designated by the Superintendent General" etc. In most other sections of the Act it adds "or his authorized agents or words to that effect," but Mr. Woodward has insisted that no one but the Superintendent General or Deputy Superintendent General has any power under this section to tell the Indians to send their children to any school.

In other words, he claims that the notices when signed by any other person than the Superintendent General or Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs are not legal and the magistrate at Penticton has called my attention to it with a request for a definite ruling on this point. Mr. Woodward says he must take advantage of any technicality in the interest of his clients, although he is quite in sympathy with efforts to send the children to school.

The attendance at Penticton has improved and some Indians have sent their children to other schools so as to avoid further trouble and I have not interfered with this arrangement as presumably the object is to have the children educated rather than have them attend any particular school. The last two families to give in had rather a rude awakening when the Penticton Municipal police arrested two boys for stealing from clothing left in the recreation park by athletes. They were caught with the stolen goods in possession and committed by the City Magistrate to the Industrial School. It was rather embarrassing to Francois Timoyakin as one of the boys was his grandson. The Indians are all beginning to admit that the children are better off in school, and while the recent trouble was unfortunate and unavoidable it is better to avoid fruit already. Some of them have admitted to me that they were afraid to send their children before because of intimidation and are glad the matter was taken out of their hands. Only those who understand the psychology of the Okanagan Indian can realise the patience and diplomacy necessary in dealing with them for their own good and the local public generally is very much in sympathy with the policy of education for Indians.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

[F.J.C.Ball]

Sir,

I have your favour of the 8th instant, No.Pn. 1-D-2, in further reference to prosecutions for truancy and with particular reference to the objection taken by the accused that the Superintendent General had not "designated" any particular school within the meaning of the Act.

In reply I have to say that the word "designated" must be construed in keeping with the general sense of the Section. The narrow construction that has been placed upon this word by the accused would imply that the Superintendent General to comply with the Act would have to write a personal letter to the parents of all the Indian children in the Dominion of Canada. Surely no one would seriously uphold such a contention. The word "designated" in the Section has a general and a particular significance. Where a school is equipped and maintained on a reserve by the Superintendent General for the education of the children residing on such reserve, as in the case of the Penticton school, that is a general designation by the Superintendent General of that school for the attendance of such children. If a child is taken away from its home and sent to some other school, on the instructions of the Superintendent General, that would be a particular designation of the school which such child would be obliged to attend. That is the intention of the Act and the interpretation which has always been placed upon it.

Your obedient servant,

F.J.C. Ball, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 31st ult. and regret that I did not explain more explicitly Mr. Woodward's technical objection. It is quite true that Section 10-2 specifically states the truant officer shall notify in writing, but Mr. Woodward's objection is under Section 10-1, which states that "every Indian child — — — shall attend such school as may be designated by the Superintendent General." Mr. Woodward contends that the Superintendent General has not designated the Penticton Indian Day School as the school which Indians on Penticton Reserve shall attend. He maintains that the parents must be notified by the Superintendent General that this is the school designated by him for the children to attend, and that no other person except the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs can so instruct them.

As pointed out in my letter of the 18th ult., all that is necessary to overcome this objection is to amend Section 10-1 by adding the words "or his agent" after the word "Superintendent General." Section 13 and other sections of the "Indian Act" have these words added, but they were omitted in Section 10-1 and the lawyer is taking advantage of the omission.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

OKANAGAN AGENCY
MONTHLY REPORT FOR MONTH OF NOVEMBER 1931

SCHOOLS

These were all inspected and progress appeared to be maintained. For the first time for a good many months the attendance at Penticton Day School was improved, ten pupils being present on November 27th. The teacher at this point Miss MacLennan, was thrown from a horse in September while riding on the reserve for recreation on a Saturday and had to take hospital treatment for a few days. Latterly, I have received several requests that the department pay her hospital account, but I do not feel that the department has any responsibility in this connection, the Okanagan Indian Day school held a sale of their work in Vernon during the week ending November 21st, but the results were not very encouraging, probably due to a combination of hard times, rather high prices, set on the work, and lack of finish to the articles. However, they are selling a fair amount of their handicrafts privately and ordinary school work is well maintained. The children of this school are making over old naval uniforms supplied by the Commissioner into school uniforms with success and thereby providing themselves with neat warm clothing.

James Coleman,
Indian Agent.

The teacher (Miss Catherine MacLennan) is, she states, suffering from neuritis. She is in my opinion suffering from some form of nerve trouble. I doubt that she is well enough at present to be teaching school. This teacher, I understand, was thrown off a horse some little time ago, and was out of school for two weeks during October. As far as I can learn from the teacher and Indian Agent, this accident took place on a Saturday, out of school hours, on the Indian Reserve. Pressure is I understand being brought to bear on the Indian Agent to recommend the payment of the teacher's hospital expenses, etc. I should recommend that the Department refuse to consider the payment of any such expense. In my opinion this teacher had no business to be riding an Indian pony on the Reserve.

I do not consider that the children are making much progress. They are very backward. The teacher has an excuse for each and every criticism that I have made. It is just a waste of my time to make any further suggestions to this teacher.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your decision following recommendation made by Inspector Barry regarding my dismissal from service as Teacher of the Penticton Indian Day School, to take effect on March 31st 1932, I beg to make the following reply.

Although I have not received from your Department any report on the reasons for my dismissal I take for granted the following are the reasons that prompted Inspector Barry to make his unfavourable decision against me. The presence of a Camp Cot in my school-room - the occasional visits of Rev. Father Cullinan to the school - and the lack of progress made by the pupils, were the topics for discussion made by Inspector Barry on his recent official visit to our school, which lasted little over an hour.

I explained to him that the Camp Cot was installed in my school-room not on my suggestion but through an act of good will of a friend of mine, Mrs Scott. After my return from the local hospital where I had been recovering for two weeks suffering from injuries received to my foot and ankle, in an accident, my ankle was still swollen and the idea of the cot was to enable me to raise my foot at noon hour. As I am alone in school at noon, and two miles from town, I was glad to have an opportunity to act on the advice of my physician and rest my ankle. Had I every anticipated that such a rumpus would be made by Inspector Barry concerning the cot I certainly would not have permitted its use. Personally however, I consider...
not a necessity in any school, but more particularly in a Rural School, and I know it is one of the first requirements of a school nurse for first aid purposes.

The second matter which obviously aroused the ire of Inspector Barry was the fact that I permitted Father Cullinan to visit the school for the purpose of giving religious instruction - when I gave him this information in reply to his questions regarding teaching religious instruction at my school his reply was "He has no right here - this is a Public School". I have never received any instructions from your Department prohibiting the visits of Father Cullinan or any other clergyman to my school - and I took for granted Father Cullinan knew his privileges.

At the close of his official inspection Mr Barry remarked that this school was backward. I grant that some of the pupils are not up to date in their work, and I shall endeavour right here to acquaint you with the reasons why they are not. The big drawback is poor attendance, and poor attendance has been due to two great reasons. One is that our unofficial Indian Chief has always been opposed to education and always will be - and it naturally follows that no assistance, co-operation or encouragement can be had from him. The other reasons are starvation and want of clothing. In this first instance I made requisition to your Department for hot lunches at school, knowing too well how this would encourage attendance, but to date this requisition has not been honoured. In the second instance I beg to state that in the past three years, were it not for the fact that I took the responsibility of clothing the pupils, there would have been no attendance at this school. The local officers of the R.C.M.P. have always been very kind in lending valuable assistance in the matter of taking the clothing from town and in the help of distribution of same to the different homes. Corp. Fenton R.C.M.P., who by the way happens to be now stationed at Ottawa, will, I am sure, request be pleased to
testify to the amount of social service work which I have rendered to my pupils. Too many times have I been obliged to buy food and clothing for pupils in order to encourage attendance, when I knew too well how poor attendance is the big hindrance to progress at school.

I feel positive that if Inspector Barry knew more of conditions existing among Indians he would not be quite so rash in putting the entire blame on the teacher.

Concerning my ability as a teacher and disciplinarian, I can only refer you to the various reports of Inspectors made on my work and accomplishments in the Public Schools of Nova Scotia and Saskatchewan. You likely have a record of my diplomas and certificates on file, and if they were not of the highest type you surely would not have invited me to come all the way from Nova Scotia to accept this position.

In conclusion I ask that consideration be given me at least for recognition in what little I have done and that my services be retained.

Very respectfully yours,

C.M. MacLennan.

Sir:

I have a copy of a letter sent by Miss C.M. MacLennan, teacher of Penticton Indian Day School, who is under notice by the Department.

While the statements contained therein are generally of a very wild nature, it appears that a comment on some of them would possibly be of assistance.

Her statement that Inspector Barry claimed that the Missionary had no right in the school is, in my opinion, absolutely incorrect and entirely contrary to the general expression of his opinion on the subject, both on this particular tour of inspection and previous inspection, when he impressed on all our teachers, in my presence the necessity for a reasonable amount of religious instruction, and it is extremely unlikely that he would advise Miss MacLennan directly contrary to the other schools and myself.

The complaint regarding the unofficial Chief, Michele Jack, is correct to some extent; but while this man is not favorable to education, he held the same position as official Chief during the period when Miss Coughlin was in charge of the school, and at that time the attendance and progress was excellent. A teacher fitted for this class of work will fill the school despite opposition from any particular section of the Band and this is evidenced by the school on Okanagan Indian Reserve No.1 under the charge of Mr. Walsh, and where the opposition has been even greater. The strongest opponents to the school are now sending their children there.

Regarding starvation and want of clothing, conditions on Penticton Reserve are somewhat better than on the Reserves north of that point. Miss MacLennan has endeavoured from time to time to act as a benefactor to the Indians - at the expense of the Department, by requesting relief for those attending school; this, in my opinion, being an attempt to make them put on an appearance, soon after taking over that she had a woman Mary McDougall, of 34, attending school as a pupil, and that she was bringing considerable pressure to bear, and through one of the R.C.M.P. to place this woman on relief to enable her to attend school. This I refused to do for the reason that in my opinion she was not a proper ward of the Department having married one Narcisse Brooks of Omak, Washington, U.S.A. in 1918, deserting him shortly after; neither of the woman's parents were Indians within the meaning of the Act, her mother being the notorious Rose Sandford, now married to an Indian of Okanagan Indian Reserve No.1. As this Mary McDougall was continually having illegitimate children, I did not consider her a fit person to have in the school. Another similar case was that of a Mrs. Marcellus and her illegitimate children.

Regarding the hot lunches, I would state that all
the children attending lived within a few minutes walk of the school and I did not consider them necessary, as the children can and do go to their own homes for lunch, which is entirely different to conditions on Okanagan Indian Reserve No.1 and Osoyoos Indian Reserve where lunches are supplied, but many of the children travel several miles to school. Concerning her alleged clothing of the pupils, I would simply state that previous teachers had a better attendance without having to do so. It is quite possible that her friends have supplied cast off clothing which she has passed on to some of the children. Corporal Fenton, now of Ottawa, to whom she refers (and who is a Catholic) may or may not support her statements regarding her alleged social work, but I am of the opinion that the general history of this school prior to Miss MacLennan's arrival will show the necessity of same.

Whatever blame Inspector Barry put on the teacher was to my mind fully justified. He was obviously dissatisfied after his visit in the spring of 1931, but reserved judgment until his next visit. I have found him absolutely fair and impartial on his inspections, although naturally he expects results. Some of his innovations have been new to the teachers, and one teacher in this Agency advised me that while he could not see that they would be successful with Indians, he would give them a trial. At a later date, he admitted that the Inspector was perfectly correct and that he was astonished at the results attained by following out these suggestions, although he admittedly had no personal confidence in them at the outset. This particular school is now operating entirely in line with the Inspector's suggestions and is very successful. I have had personal experience as a school trustee and a teacher for a short period, and consider that I am justified in my opinion that Miss MacLennan's reflections on the Inspector are entirely without foundation, and that his attitude in this agency has been entirely friendly and helpful to the teachers in regard to their difficulties.

With reference to Miss MacLennan's request that her services be retained, I prefer to make no comment as, no doubt, the decision of the Department was reached after careful consideration of all information available in the case.

I have the honour to be,

SIR,
Your obedient servant,

(James Coleman)
Indian Agent.

ORIGINAL ON NO. 164-10-6.

All the children on the local Indian Reserve do not attend school, either here or elsewhere. It might be well now that the status of the Indians in the Okanagan has been determined to insist that all children attend school unless there is a definite reason why they should not do so. This matter was mentioned in my last report on this school, and it will be remembered that I there suggested that the Department request the Indian Agent to report on all children living on the Penticton Indian Reserve who did not attend one or other of the Indian schools. I do not know if the Department has now received such information, or if it has issued any instructions with regard to such children. Three children belonging to the George family mentioned in my last report are now attending school at the Kamloops Indian Residential School. It would be a pity to close this school, and I am quite certain that with some effort it would be possible to increase the attendance, which is now very small. It has been drawn to my attention that Miss C. M. McLellan, teacher at the Indian Reserve School at Penticton is to be dismissed from her school at the end of next month.

After three years acquaintance with Miss McLellan I cannot quite conceive of such action being taken against her because she has at all times evinced a most thorough-going professional attitude toward her work and taken a real pride in the progress of her pupils.

She has always been on excellent terms with all the members of my staff and when in contact with us educational problems and progressive methods of teaching have invariably been discussed with genuine enthusiasm. To my mind she strives always to keep abreast of the times and endeavors at all times to give her young charges the advantages that modern methods can afford.

On several occasions she has taken advantage of the equipment a large school affords and it has been my pleasure to give her copies of various types of work in Arithmetic, Geography, History, etc.,

To me, her attitude towards her work and the seriousness with which she discusses it have always given the impression of a sound and progressive worker.

Really, I cannot quite conceive of anything like dismissal coming into the life of Miss McLellan. The case, I think, deserves your most serious consideration because, if she has to go, I fear a real injustice through misunderstanding will have been done.

Sir:

re: Your File No.164-10-1.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 14th ultimo with reference to Mr. Inspector Barry's report regarding attendance at Penticton Indian Day School, and to advise that there are approximately 15 Indian children living within one mile of this school, and not attending same.

The Penticton Band petitioned the Department on December 21st 1921, the petition being signed by 16 members of the Band, and the school was built in 1923, but after it was opened a number of the petitioners commenced to oppose it, and finally, in 1925, my predecessor in office, Mr. Ball, attempted to enforce attendance and eventually issued summonses under the "Indian Act" to several parents, which were ignored. Bench warrants were issued, and when the R.C.M.P. attempted to put them into effect, some eighty-odd Indians opposed them by force and the officers were considerably mauled, one Indian coming seeking the gun of one of the officers, and probably would have used it, but for the prompt action of the R.C.M.P. Inspector. The arrests were made and convictions ensued, and there the matter rested, no increase in school attendance being effected.

In my opinion, the matter resolves itself into the fact that if we propose to enforce school attendance, there will be more or less a repetition of the previous trouble, but if the enforcement is once commenced, it should be followed through to the limit; otherwise not opened up at all. So far I have taken the attitude with the Penticton Band of endeavouring to sell them the idea of education, rather than legal enforcement, but I must admit that there has been no noticeable result. This attitude was taken largely for the reason that if an issue were made of the question, it placed those Indians who were sending their children to school in a rather difficult position, until such time as general enforcement were effected.

It seems to be an Indian idea in this Agency to petition the Department for something, and when we attempt to carry out their wishes, to have a large number of the original petitioners make an issue of the matter, and actively oppose it. This has happened twice in my experience on Okanagan I.R.No.1 and Okanagan I.R.No.9.

I am rather inclined to the opinion that if the attendance at this school is not considered commensurate with the expenditure, it might prove more effective to inform the
Band that unless they propose to give better support to the institution by the end of the present term, no further educational facilities will be provided, and close the school; and if it is re-opened in future, it would only remain open as long as the average attendance was maintained at a minimum of 25 pupils. It is problematical whether or not this would have the desired result, but in my opinion it is the most effective manner in dealing with the type of Indian we have in this Agency, and at the same time put it up definitely to the more progressive element to exert a greater measure of pressure on the backward element. If, however, the Department feels that attendance should be enforced, I will inform the Indians of our intentions and the B.O.O. in charge of the R.C.M.P. at Penticton to enforce attendance two weeks after my notice to the Indians.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

(James Coleman)
Indian Agent.

Dear Mr. Barber,

I thank you for your letter dated March 11th. As Napoleon has not been here since I wrote you, I presume he has received a letter from you giving the information he asked for. I am sorry to hear from you that Napoleon has such a poor record, but perhaps like many other young people, he will become wiser as he grows older especially if he marries and settles down.

There is another matter I wish to write to you about, perhaps you will kindly look into this and see what can be done.

The matter has been brought to my notice that Joseph Kruger would like his three children to attend the Penticton public school. I am informed that the Penticton Indian Day School has been closed since last October when Mrs. Macdonald, the teacher became indisposed, and that it has not been re-opened since, consequently, the children are without education. I gather that the school bus passes the Kruger's door as their house is situated on the main road.

I believe the Department would be willing to pay the tuition fees if the School Board would accept the youngsters. You will recollect that the Oliver School took in young girls from Inkonseep last year so I do not anticipate the Penticton public school raising objection. Perhaps you would make enquires and see what can be done providing all the facts are as presented to me.

Perhaps you will forgive me if I touch upon a personal matter. I cannot help feeling that you resent my asking you from time to time for information or assistance for the Indians. In doing so, it is not my wish to intrude into affairs coming within your jurisdiction, my action is motivated by the desire to help both the Indians and the Department and it is for this reason I approach you. The Indians and their problems are our concern," Mr. Jennesse said, "they are bewildered and confused" and whatever an individual can do, he should do.

For this reason I would like to ask that we meet from time to time in a friendly way and talk matters over. Please be assured Mr. Barber that my only wish is to help both you and the Indians, perhaps between us we might be able to guide them, for it is a lead they are looking for.

It will give me pleasure if you will ring me up when you are next in Oliver, I repeat my oftmade invitation that you will be very welcome at any time you may call to see me, or if you are too busy to come out, I will meet you in town.

With kind regards,

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Dear Mr. Davey,

I inaugurated night classes in for adults three evenings a week from 6:30 to 9:00 for approximately ten weeks. The original plan was to teach reading and writing to a few of the older people who were without those skills but so many others ask if they might not attend that I found myself with an advanced class. I was pleased because it is such a good example to my own pupils, and to their parents many of whom are now pupils too. I decided their main need was everyday arithmetic and language, and because of the Clubwork I started, have also taught them how to conduct meetings properly and have been giving them a background of Canadian history. We have accomplished quite a bit of work. The Indians are quite handicapped by living so close to town. It seems as though they never thought it worthwhile to organize their own community as they could always drift in and loaf around in town. However, they were too busy to do that this winter for besides the night classes on Mondays, Thursdays, and Fridays I have a Women's Club for handicrafts on Wednesday evening, and my husband has organized a men's club to teach them carpentry.

Although this has taken most of my time I am anxious to continue the work next year. Could you supply me with the names of teachers working along this line, or any books that you have found useful guides in this line of adult education? I would like to learn more about cooperative projects but the groundwork can only be built slowly as there are two or three quite wealthy old Indians who will not be bothered about the others. I have quite a nice group of younger ones who are anxious to learn more modern methods.

Will you give me authority to requisition both sets of readers for Grades III and IV? The group of beginners that I started with last year read very well. We finished the 'These are our Neighbours' shortly after Christmas and are reading the old Highroads Grades III and III. I have checked with the classes in town and feel that my advanced group are very good indeed.

The school is being wired for electricity and we are planning a 'Light Up' celebration on March 17.

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]

22 Enrolled In Indian Night School Classes

Mr. R. P. Murray, district horticulturist at Penticton, was guest speaker at the adult education class held at the Indian day school last Friday evening.

The classes, which began in January, are held three times weekly under the direction of the day school teacher, Mrs. H. E. Hayes.

In all, 22 persons from the Indian Reserve have registered for the beginners' and advanced classes. Cold weather has hampered attendance.

A variety of subjects are offered, from reading and writing for the beginners to land use, agriculture and Canadian history and government for the advanced group.

Mrs. Hayes, in an issue of "Smoke Signals," the school newspaper, reports that the classes are making excellent progress.

As well as publishing day and night classes near the paper also intends to reproduce original stories, poems, drawings, or articles pertaining to Indian culture such as legends, beliefs and handicrafts.

Most important, however, to be brought out at the Friday session was the need of an irrigation system for the reservation lands. It was pointed out that the water supply dwindles around the middle of July and that very seldom is there a sufficient supply during August.

With an adequate supply of water, it was felt, approximately 500 acres could be cultivated.

One result of the meeting will be that all cattle on the reservation will be sprayed this year to counteract "warbles." It was pointed out that in the Similkameen area, spraying over a period of time had almost completely removed this menace.

Mr. Murray was thanked by Chief Gideon Eness and Mrs. Hayes.

Those enrolled for the adult education classes are as follows: Beginners: Mrs. Angela Eness, Mrs. Helen Alex, Mrs. Susan Kruger, John Kruger, Joe Kruger, Felix Lezard, Elisabeth Felix, Antoine Felix; Advanced: Amelia Gabriel, Annie Eness, Mrs. Phillip, Edward Gabriel, Paul Gabriel, Anna Eness, Jacob Kruger, Irene Antoine, James George, Francis Phillip, Lizzie Lezard, Narcisse Gabriel, Louise Gabriel and Gleon Eness.

W.S. Arniel, Esq., Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver.

Some members of Penticton Band have formed a club which they have named the "Arrow Club", and have applied for assistance to pay an instructor. Mr. Jack Hayes, husband of the school teacher at Penticton, is a qualified carpenter and offers his services for this purpose. As a matter of fact, Mr. Hayes has been instructing the Indians in this course for several weeks.

The original plan of the Club was to learn carpentry so they would be able to construct better homes, furniture, etcetera. Their present plans include the construction of a community hall on the reserve and Mr. Hayes has promised to supervise this work in connection with the Club activities.

The activities of this men's club is co-ordinated with the Homemaker's Club, organized by Mrs. Hayes, the teacher, and both clubs participate in an adult education programme which has been organized by Mrs. Hayes. Mr. Hayes' services will consist of three hours instruction every Wednesday evening and he will use his own tools for this purpose. He has signified that compensation of $20.00 per month would be satisfactory to him, and if you feel that this expense is warranted and funds are available for such purposes, I would be pleased to have this expense authorized.

R.H.S. Sampson,
Superintendent,
Okanagan Indian Agency.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. Citizenship & Immigration
Ottawa, Ont.

Mr. Sampson recently discussed this matter with District School Inspector Davey who is inclined to favour the proposal and who reports very favourably with regard to the activities of the Arrow Club. Mr. Sampson's suggestion is recommended for favourable consideration on a trial basis for a period of four months from March 1st.

Dear Mr. Ball:

Upon Mr. Cairns' visit here he advised me of the discontinuation of the bonus at the end of March. Have you any definite intimation of this?

I had always felt confident that when the bonus was discontinued the Department would adjust the salary. Although this is in discussion, Mr. Cairns entertains no high hopes of this being done.

I feel quite badly over this as my length of service and work increases, my income decreases—truly a very discouraging fact.

I shall be very grateful for any information you may have on this subject.

Mr. Cairns appeared well pleased with the pupils' progress. He was agreeably surprised to see the new building.

Sir:

I have your 15/10/23592 of the 7th instant, submitting the report of Mr. Barry on his inspection of the Penticton Indian Day School, and recommending that the services of Miss Catherine M. MacLennan be dispensed with, for the reasons stated by him, as from the end of March, next.

In reply I have to say that, in view of the Inspector's recommendation, you should inform the local Indian Agent that he is to notify Miss MacLennan that her services will not be required after March 31st, next.

Please arrange with Mr. Barry to obtain the services of a qualified Roman Catholic teacher to succeed Miss MacLennan, to begin duties on or about April 1st, next. The appointment of the teacher whom you nominate should be concurred in by Archbishop Duke, 616 Richards St., Vancouver, as he has requested that all changes in teachers of schools conducted under the auspices of the Catholic Church in British Columbia be approved by him. Please forward, in due time, for the approval of the Department, the name, qualifications and experience of the teacher whom the Inspector and yourself recommend be appointed after receiving the concurrence of Archbishop Duke. If a qualified teacher is obtained, the salary allowed her would be at the same rate as was paid Miss MacLennan, viz., $100 per teaching month.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, Nov. 13, 1922.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge your letter of the 11th ultimo, referring to the Lenticton Indian Day School. I have noted that the present accommodation is inadequate and that the new school should be erected as soon as possible.

In reply I beg to state that there has been an unavoidable delay in this connection, and I regret to inform you that it will be necessary to postpone building operations at this school until next year. It is noted that this building need not provide teacher's living quarters.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,

November 13, 1922.

Memo for File:

Indian Education Vote 1921-22 provided for the Okanagan Indian Day School, but the building was never erected. Indian Education Vote 1922-23 provided for Salmon River and Penticton Indian Day Schools - neither of these schools will be built, but the money voted for the Salmon River School is being used for the Okanagan School. These last mentioned day schools are situated close together and have been confused on the files - thus the indecision regarding building.

The File Numbers are: Okanagan 164-5, Penticton 164-10, Salmon River 558462.

R.T.F.
IN YOUR REPLY REFER TO

No.

ALSO

TO DATE OF THIS LETTER

Sir,

I beg to advise in reply to your letter of the 16th August last that the tenders for the Okanagan Day School were duly forwarded on the 4th September but no reply has yet been received.

As the roads out to the Reserve are not good after the weather breaks up, construction should be commenced as soon as possible if the work is to be completed this year.

With reference to the temporary arrangement at Penticton whereby we are using the priest's house, this is very crowded and inconvenient for the 20 pupils enrolled and no others can be taken in. I hope the Department will find it possible to have building operations commenced there in the near future. This school will not include teacher's residence and will be smaller than the Okanagan School.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Sir,

I beg to refer to your letter of November 15, 1922, with reference to the construction of a day school on the Penticton Reserve.

Since September last the priest's house, which is the property of the Indians, has been used, but it is crowded with eighteen to twenty pupils and in hot weather will be decidedly uncomfortable, if not impossible. The opposition to education has lessened materially since the school was started and I think too much attention has been paid in the past to the objections of ignorant members of the Band, both here and elsewhere. Anyone who sees the scholars and the other children together must be struck with the great difference already shown between them and I hope to see every Indian child in the Agency being educated, not merely for their own good, but for the good influence these children already have in their homes which is shown by increased attention to personal cleanliness, neatness of their homes, and other ways.

At the risk of being considered importunate, I respectfully request that the question of a school building on Penticton Reserve be given early attention.

There is only one school building in this Agency, the one opened this year on the Okanagan Reserve, although three schools are operating. As far as Indian opposition is concerned, I have noticed that every move I
Ass't. Dep. and Sec'y......(2)

have made to improve or advance their condition has always been opposed by some of them, but if attention is paid to this party the Bands will remain in their present state indefinitely. Of course educating the children is only a means to an end, viz. the improvement in their standard of living generally.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Sir,

I beg to refer to your letter of March 22nd last with reference to the erection of the day school at Penticton Indian Reserve.

The building which we have been using is too small to accommodate all the children who wish to attend and has been badly over-crowded since it has been used. I hope that the construction of the new day school can be proceeded with so that it can be ready for occupancy when school re-opens after the summer vacation. Only a small school is necessary and need not include a teacher's residence as it is within two miles of town and the present teacher has no difficulty in living in Penticton and teaching on the Reserve. Very good work has been accomplished and the children have made splendid progress under adverse conditions, but for health reasons they should not be kept in the small room at present in use longer than is absolutely necessary.

2. That if the Contractors fail at any time to pay any account for any goods or materials supplied, or money advanced by anyone to the said Contractors for the purposes of this agreement, or to pay the account of any sub-contractor for any work or materials done or supplied for the said works to be constructed under this agreement, and such
account is in either of such cases one month overdue, the Superintendent General may notify the Contractors to pay such account and if a week elapse and the same be not paid in full, the Superintendent General may pay such account and may charge the same to the Contractors, and the Contractors covenant with the Superintendent General to repay at once any and every sum so paid.

3. That if the Contractors fail at any time in paying salaries or wages of any person employed by them upon or in respect of the said works, or any of them, and any part of such salary is one month in arrear, or if there be due to any such person one month's wages or salary, the Superintendent General may notify the Contractors to pay such salary or wages, and if two days elapse and the same be not paid in full up to date of payment, or to such other date as may be in accordance with the terms of employment of such person, then the Superintendent General may pay to such person his salary or wages from any date to any date and to any amount which may be payable, and may charge the same to the Contractors and the Contractors covenant with the Superintendent General to repay at once any and every sum so paid.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 12th instant, regarding the proposed establishment of a summer school at Fort McLeod.

In this connection I have to inform you that the sum of $200 will be available in the Appropriation for Indian Education for the coming fiscal year towards the cost of completion of a suitable building. I would refer to your letter dated August 18th, last, in which you stated that the above amount would be the maximum required and should cover the cost of the floor, shingles, lumber for roof, windows and doors, and might allow something for a stove, stove pipe, and roof jack. It is noted that a further sum of $75 would be required to purchase material for the purpose of building desks of the old-fashioned type, with seats attached.

It is understood that the Indians will get out any logs required and do the work of erecting a building.

You may therefore arrange for the purchase of the materials required to complete the building and for the construction of the desks, to a total cost not exceeding $275. The Department is not prepared to supply standard desks at this point until we are assured that the work is successful. It is considered that wooden desks, made locally, would be satisfactory.

Please arrange for the purchase, from firms on the approved list, and have the materials forwarded to the site. You should supervise the work and arrange with the Indians to perform the labour. If it is intended that classes be conducted during the coming summer months, you should see that the work of completing the building is proceeded with as soon as possible. Please obtain itemized accounts, in triplicate, stating in detail the building materials purchased. These, you should attach to proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and forward for payment. In this connection it should be understood, however, that as the appropriation will not be available until after April first, next, payment of accounts cannot be made before that date.

If you find that the construction of the building is progressing satisfactorily and that it will be completed in time to open the school this coming summer, you may take up with the church authorities the question of nominating a suitable teacher. The name, qualifications and experience of the teacher nominated should be forwarded for the approval of the Department. The date on which it is intended to open the school and the length of time it will be conducted should be stated.

You are being written in a separate communication regarding the proposed summer school at Fort Grahame.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Sir:

I beg to attach hereto the attendance report of the Fort McLeod Summer school, along with a report from the teacher, which I trust you will find satisfactory.

While on the subject of schools I wish to say that the total expenditure for school buildings both at Fort McLeod and Fort Graham this year amounted to approximately $120.00 out of the amount of $450.00 authorized by the Department. The new school at Fort McLeod was not completed last spring in time to hold school in, so that the church was used. However, now it is ready, except for the roof, windows and other material which will have to be shipped in and which will cost approximately $185.00 landed at the head of the waterways so that the Indians can get it. I would suggest that we allow the Indians sufficient gasoline to take the material down the river and lakes by boats and which should cost about $30.00 so that the $185.00 for material plus $30.00 for gasoline would be $215.00 and if agreeable to the Department I propose to make this purchase now of the money that is available and have it ready to go in first thing next May. This will make the total expenditure of $335.00 and the balance of $115.00 could be returned to the Treasury. Please advise me in this connection at your convenience.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.
Sir:

I would respectfully refer you to your letter of October the 19th last, File No. 163-125 relative to the purchase of material to complete the Indian Day School at Fort McLeod Indian Reserve. In November last Voucher No. 8276 was submitted from this office in favour of the Andersen Lumber Yard for the supplies in question, which with transportation charges from Prince George to Summit Lake amounted to $183.02. There is, however, a charge of approximately $20.00 for gasoline and oil for the Indians to take this material from Summit Lake down to Fort McLeod. This account however is not being submitted by me at this time as I deem it advisable not to buy goods of this nature until they are going to be delivered as there might be a difference in the price of gasoline and oil in the spring. I would, therefore, esteem it a favour if you would kindly give me the necessary authority to buy two barrels of gasoline and ten gallons of oil to be given to the Indians as soon as they come to Summit Lake early in May. The reason I am asking for this authority now is so that no delay will occur after the Indians arrive at Summit Lake. You will please understand that owing to no means of communication between Summit Lake and here it will not be possible for me to know when the Indians are coming until they actually arrive at Prince George, consequently I want to have everything ready for them when they do come.

While I am on the subject of the Schools at Fort McLeod and Fort Graham I wish to advise that Mr. Cormack will again be available to teach at McLeod but we will have to get a new one for Fort Graham as Mr. ... will not be able to come up there this year. I have had one or two applications for the position at Fort Graham but owing to the lack of information given I had to return them to the applicants and ask that they give fuller information regarding themselves and their qualifications. Before I submit the applications to the Department for approval I will have them agreed to by the local church authorities who are in charge of those missions.

In the meantime would you be kind enough to advise me definitely if the salaries are going to be the same this year as last, and if it will be possible for the Department to consider a small grant towards travelling expenses for these boys getting from Prince George to Forts McLeod and Graham. As you know transportation costs down the rivers and lakes is quite an expense and even a grant of $15.00 or $20.00 to each teacher would certainly help a lot. Please advise in this connection.

Your obedient servant,

R.H. Moore,
Indian Agent.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

With reference to Departmental letter No.168-10-5 of May 6th last in regard to the remarks of School Inspector Brown in his report of the Penticton Indian Day School as to the condition of the walls and ceiling of the class-room, which should be re-decorated,

I now submit a tender on this work and would recommend that authority be granted to have the interior of this school re-decorated at a cost of $195.00, as covered in Plan 2 of the attached which calls for a two coat job, by T.J.Kane, Penticton.

The walls and ceiling are in such condition that a two coat job is necessary.

The delay in requesting this authority is due to my being unable before this time to obtain any quotation on the work, all the painters being so busy and short of labour.

An early reply will be appreciated in order that I can arrange for the work to be done as soon as possible.

I would advise that the heater in use at Penticton Indian Day School is worn out and should be replaced for this winter's heating of the school.

On my visit to the school on the 24th instant, I found on inspection that the heater is in very bad condition, the lining not only burnt through but the metal back of the heater also having a large hole burnt through and all the joints warped and parted. The heater has had to be repaired each year for the past four years but I now recommend that a new heater of the circulatory type, coal burning, be supplied before the cold weather arrives.

I have enquired locally and no suitable heaters are available and therefore cost of one can not be quoted.

Size of class-room is approximately 26'x30'.

Reference is made to District School Inspector Davey's report covering his inspection of the Penticton Indian Day School which was forwarded to you under cover of my letter of May 9th, particularly that section dealing with the condition of the building and outhouses.

Mr. Hett, in his letter of July 11th and enclosures attached, outlines the repairs necessary and the cost of same. You will note that general repairs are estimated to cost $453.60 and that Jack Hayes, contractor at Penticton, is prepared to supply all material and labour for this sum, and that interior and exterior painting will cost $711.20 for material and labour.

No specific provision was made in the Estimates for this work but according to Mr. Davey, with whom I have discussed the matter, the general repairs should be made this year and the painting could, if funds cannot be made available, be postponed until next year. I should appreciate being advised what funds can be made available for this school and if Mr. Hayes' tenders can be accepted. W.S. Arneil, Esq., Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
Vancouver.

Re: Penticton Indian Day School

With reference to your letter of May 9th, file 10-11-5, and the District School Inspector's report, I enclose herewith an estimate of the cost of work that should be done on the Penticton Indian Day School this summer.

Both the boys and girls' toilets are in very poor shape and must be replaced.

The chimney now in the school is in good condition but is right in the centre of the front wall of the school, which means the pipes have to run over the teacher's desk, and the stove is between the desk and the class. If it was moved back to the wall it would take up too much of the blackboard space and would not heat the other end of the classroom where the doors are situated.

The chimney now required would be at the side of the school, near the back, and the stove would be behind the class. It would be less expensive to build a new chimney out of blocks (which are considered as good as bricks), than to take the brick chimney down and rebuild it.

The other items, cupboards and shelves, et cetera are all necessary.
W.S. Arneil, Esq., - 2 - July 11th, 1949.

Extract from Inspector Barry's report on the Penticton Indian Day School, Okanagan Agency, which he inspected on January 24.

I am very anxious that the Vocational Training of the girls should be extended at this school. In my last report on the school I recommended that a Singer sewing machine be supplied, and paid for out of the B.C. Special Vote. So far the school has not been given the machine recommended by me, and requested by the Indian Agent. Should such a machine be supplied the girls would be able to make a number of their own clothes in school, and on graduation would be able to make better use of the machines to be found in almost all the Indian homes.

(Sgd.) Gerald H. Barry
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

In forwarding this report Commissioner MacKay states that the recommendation of the Inspector with respect to the supply of a Singer sewing machine is concurred in.
EX'D.

You should arrange with the teacher to have the Express Agent at Penticton advise her when the machine arrives in order that she may have it delivered to the school.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,

Sir,

In reply to your letter No 121237/I relative to the teacher at Port Essington Indian Day school, I beg to remind you that some time ago I suggested that the grants for school teachers be paid through the Indian Agent instead of through the Church authorities, in order that matters of the kind might be facilitated.

The Department then thought that it appeared advisable to continue the arrangements already in vogue.

It is not only at Port Essington that teachers have changed, but also at Port Simpson, Luk-kalzkap, and Gitlakdamsike. It was in connection with the latter that the suggestion referred to was offered. I thought it would be easier to keep in touch with the changes made from time to time. In the case of Miss Bland the change was made by the Church authorities, and I did not know that Miss Bland was in Port Essington until I received the report for the quarter.

I understand the school was taught by Rev. Mr. Pierce during the first part of the quarter. Miss Tranter is on a year's vacation, and is not likely to return to Port Essington.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

The new school house that I reported on my former inspection as not being properly completed, has been strengthened by the contractor, and is now in good shape. It has not been used as yet.

Sir,

I have the honor to report that when visiting Fort Rossington last month I found that the Day School had been closed since the 4th of May 1911, when Miss Bland (only taught two months — a good teacher) left the school under instructions from the Rev. T. Perrier who informed her that they did not have the funds to keep her. I believe he expected the Missionary, the Rev. W.H. Pierce to teach, but he refused, as he did not have time (nor is he qualified).

The former teacher, Miss K. Tranter, having taught the school for twenty years or more was granted a year's furlough with pay by the Church authorities, but the Indians were told that she would return as teacher at the end of her furlough. At the end of January, 1912, Miss Tranter was sent to Bella Bella School.

I found the Rossington Indians very much aggrieved by this. They stated that the premises made that Miss Tranter would return to their school after her holiday had been broken, and they requested that if the Church does not open the school, that the Department furnish them a teacher.

I found there were twenty-two children of school age in the village that had been home all winter, and their parents are anxious for them to be at school. During 1910 and the first part of 1911 a number of the Rossington Indians went up the Skeena cutting wood, etc., for the railway construction camps, but when the work was finished near by they returned to the village.

This school can be kept open ten months and a half of the year, and it is important that a suitable teacher be in charge.

I talked this matter over with Rev. G.M. Haley of Fort Simpson District of the Methodist Church, and he assured me that they would have the school reopened very soon, not later than April 1st.

Dear Sir,

I am taking the liberty of writing you in order to express my views regarding the education of Indian children in this village.

During the past few years conditions have changed very much. Formerly, it was easy to secure a good attendance at the Day School for the greater part of the year, but it is very difficult. Civilization has come. Whites and foreigners are all around us. This makes it more difficult for the Indians to earn their living at home, and when he moves out, whether it be to fish camp, hunting ground, logging camp, or other places of employment that have opened up since the whites...
came, his wife and children go too.

Here, any progress that has been made at school during the period they have been able to attend, is all lost during the next few weeks or months absence, and on their return, the teacher has to begin and go over the same ground again, thus no real progress to the child and both teacher and pupil are discouraged.

A large sum of money is expended by the government year by year to carry on these Day Schools, and educate the Native children. And it seems as if so little is accomplished as a result. May I suggest what in my opinion could be a change for the better? I refer to a Boarding School—a small building to accommodate say about twenty-five or thirty.

If we had such a building, the parents of these children would place them there instead of taking them away at intervals. Many many times they have come to me before leaving, say "I am only to
have to take my children away from school, but I cannot leave them behind, for there is no place where they can stay."

The Indians living at Port Essington are two tribes, formerly belonging to the Kit-um-Kalen village, which is a distance of almost forty miles up the river, and to Kit-se-las, which is another village about six or eight miles further above that.

At the time of the construction, some of the families moved there in order that they might work on the G. J. and P. Canal; they took their children along.

At Kit-um-Kalen, there are about ten children of school age, and no school. Early in spring, they come down here for the summer's work, where their children attend school here until the holidays begin. These people often say how much better it would be if their children could attend school the whole of the year, so that if a boarding school were here, they would be glad to leave them.
At Kik-e-las, there is a school, but there,
a mile, the attendance is irregular, and from
the same cause.

If a small building were erected here at Port
Esquimalt, the children belonging to these three
places could all be taken in and receive
regular instruction and make good progress
that would satisfy the government, and be
very pleasing to their parents.

The government has been especially fond
in doing their utmost to educate and
develop the Indian race; therefore these
few suggestions will I trust be helpful
to them in their future plans for further
development.

Before closing, I might add, that as a mis-
sionary, I have known these people for about
34 years. They moved down in a body with
all their children and belongings right from
their heathen homes surroundings at that
time, in order to live a Christian life, and
be taught in the Christian way.

I was sent here here as missionary
teacher. In three days there were no
whites living here except one man, Mr. Robert Crosthwaite by name, the leader.

After remaining with these people a short time, I was sent to another field in the Upper St. Lawrence. Six years ago we were moved from our home up here to again came at this mission. During the years that intervened from my first coming here till now, I have been in close touch with this people, having always come down in spring with the upper river Indians on the fishing season. I stayed at the mouth of the river until the fishing closed.

You will have readily see how I have watched and followed all the many changes that have taken place during that time. That same valley has given me several experiences. In those early days, there was only a steamer calling occasionally among the Indians; canoes were the only mode of travelling then a most wonderful change came, when river boats began to operate up and down the river. We could travel to Toronto in a few days instead of taking two weeks a mile. Then more wonderful still was the coming of the railroad, trains into the place.
of chambers. How we can arrive at Hazelton in a few hours from starting.

Will you respond in your valuable time any further. At any time you desire all information that I could give I shall be pleased to answer any question in the best of my knowledge.

I beg to remain

Yours Respectfully,

W.H. Pierce

There is a very definite reason for the failure of the children during the past year. There are too many children for this rather elderly teacher. It will also be understood that I have done everything possible to help the teacher with regard to methods, etc. She is however rather too old to make much use of my "Demonstration and Type Lessons". Her knowledge of the Psychology of Teaching is in my opinion very limited, hence she does not get the best results, and her pupils suffer. Mrs. Pogson is nearing the end of her teaching career, and I am afraid that it will not be very long before she forces me to ask the Department to make a change of teachers here. I think that a letter from the Department to this teacher stating that her work has not been considered very satisfactory during the past year by the Inspector of Schools might result in some improvement in the work.

The 10 children who cannot be considered as Indians within the meaning of the Indian Act were taken off the Register by the teacher on instructions of Mr. Indian Agent Collison.

There is not sufficient seating accommodation for the Indian children and the extra 10 children now attending this school. In addition, the teacher is not able to teach all the children with success. The standard of the work is thus falling and nothing that I can do will improve matters.

I have therefore to recommend that the ten children at present attending this school who are not Indians, and this includes the teacher's own little girl, be EXCLUDED FROM THE INDIAN DAY SCHOOL. I understand that they will be admitted to the local Provincial Day School, which is located within a few hundred yards. I also understand that it is the wish of the Provincial Inspector of Schools for this District that these children be sent to the Provincial School. I agree with him.
him in every way. I would ask that definite instructions be sent to the Indian Agent, Mr. W. E. Collison, to instruct the teacher, Mrs. Pogson, to exclude all children who are not Indians from the Port Essington Indian Day School. This will make the provision of new single desks less necessary and give the teacher a chance to pull up the general standard of the work in the Primary Grades.

As I am not anxious to recommend that a new teacher be appointed here at the present time, I have taken the only remaining course and recommended a reduction in the number of children to be taught. The children who attend the school while living on the Indian Reserve though not Indians belong to two families. There are good reasons I understand why these particular families should be allowed to remain on the Indian Reserve. The child of the teacher is falling back in her work and I consider she too should attend the Provincial School, and be taught by someone other than her mother.

No doubt, the Department will wish for a full report on the matters mentioned above from the Indian Agent. I may say that these matters have been discussed with Mr. Indian Agent Collison on several occasions during the past two years, and I believe we are in complete agreement with regard to the necessity for the exclusion of the NON INDIAN CHILDREN in this case, without laying down any general rule which must be followed in all such cases.

DETRACT FROM LETTER FROM MRS. LOUISE PARKLEY,
Port Essington, B.C.-Sept.18/29.

Dear Mr. Barnet:

I have been here since the beginning of the month but have only had school two days on account of measles epidemic, with new cases coming up all the time, but outside of that I have decided I cannot stay here. I could not live in the hospital, it is too large and barn-like for one person to stay in alone and the kitchen which I would have to use is horribly dirty and I would not begin to clean it. Dr. Large then gave me permission to stay in the nurses' home and I went to work and fixed up two rooms and bought a stove and linoleum for the floor and several other things and stayed there a few nights but could not put up with it. There are drunken men ranging around this town and fighting every night and it is not safe for any woman to live alone. You will know I am not exaggerating facts for I have lived alone before several times and am not nervous, but in view of the fact that terrible things have happened here I think the Department should be approached and a mounted policeman should be stationed here for a time and get the place cleaned up, for it is the Indians who drink and fight and some of the worst offenders live right next door to where I have to live.

The measles will likely keep the school closed for some time and you will have time to arrange for another teacher. I am going to Hazelton in the meantime and after awhile you might find some place else for me. I would just as soon go back to the prairie as have this to put up with. I don't really want to give up the work but this experience has not been very pleasant and I have been in bed for a week staying with Mrs. Hunt whom I knew in Hazelton. There is no place to board here or I would have managed that way.
