Mr. Severson informs me that he is an applicant for the position of teacher in an Indian School under your Board and has requested that I furnish you with a report on his teaching experience in Saskatchewan.

Mr. Severson's work was inspected by Inspector J.P. Muller, B.A., B.Ed., of Weyburn on June 10, 1932 in Range View School District #599. Inspector Muller's report in part is as follows:

"Mr. Severson is a highly promising teacher. He aims to provide purposeful work that interests and satisfies. His method of teaching has a very strong tendency towards the projects idea. His questions are well selected and require considerable thought. His classroom manner is pleasing and his discipline is good...He is well liked by the pupils and ratepayers." Mr. Muller's general estimate is "highly promising."

In this school he had twenty-one pupils from Grades 1 to VIII inclusive.

On May 29, 1933 Inspector Muller saw Mr. Severson's work in the same school with the same grades. In general his report is along similar lines to the former one. He states the discipline is good and that the pupils are making average progress, although some of them appear to be over graded.

On October 10, 1933 Inspector Muller saw Mr. Severson's work again at Tenhild School, District #1060. He had fifteen pupils in Grades 1, II, IV, V, VII, IX and X. He reported that the pupils were making average progress.

On September 11, 1935 in Dravland School District #947 Mr. Muller again inspected Mr. Severson's work. He had thirty pupils in Grades 1 to VII inclusive. On the occasion of this visit while commenting on Mr. Severson's good personality...
and the good organization of his work he criticized Mr. Severson's assignments as being not sufficiently definite and searching. He found that the pupils were interested, responded well and that the general tone and discipline of the school were good.

On September 16, 1936 Mr. Severson's school was inspected by Inspector J.R. Fraser of Radville. There were twenty-nine pupils in Grades 1 to VIII inclusive. Mr. Fraser comments favorably on the organization of the work, the classroom management and the provision of purposeful seat work. He describes Mr. Severson as a conscientious teacher of a very good type who should give satisfactory service.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I am in receipt of a letter from Dr. Osterhout, our Superintendent of Missions, regarding the nomination of a Teacher who would also be the Missionary at this point. As you know, it is very difficult to get the type of man who will do both jobs satisfactorily, and, as far as I am concerned, I have grave doubts about the wisdom of having two persons at this village. I do not think that the work warrants it.

Last year we had Mr. Severson there, and I gathered that, whilst his work was to a certain extent acceptable, yet it was not of a sufficiently high character as to warrant his continuance at that particular point.

Dr. Osterhout has written nominating Mr. Andrew Rutherford for this position. Mr. Rutherford is 52 years of age. He has his B. A. from McMaster University. He is a graduate of the Springfield V.M.C.A. College, Springfield, Mass., and he holds a First Class Saskatchewan Permanent Certificate. He has had 7 years' teaching experience, 3 of which were spent in Japan. He has been Vice-Principal of a 7-room Public School. In his application he says that he will, at the first opportunity, take the Summer School Course in Education in British Columbia and acquire British Columbia standing. I do not know just what your rules are, but I would judge that there has been no hard and fast procedure governing these appointments as far as Provincial standing is concerned, provided the Teacher has proper qualifications somewhere else.

I shall be glad to hear from you in connection with this appointment at your earliest convenience.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Sirs:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of Nov. 20th, giving us information as to how the salaries are made up for Mr. Vannatter and Mr. More. I confess that I am astonished to find that, contrary to the instructions provided on the back of the National Defence Form N.D.T.1, a deduction has been made in these cases for National Defence Tax. Section 9 of the form which I have before me says: "Rate of tax in the case of a married person - 2 per cent if the income exceeds $1,200 per year". It is quite obvious that this is an old form and that it should be 5 per cent, but I note it says that the rate is applicable to the total income.

Now of course it is ridiculous, if I may use the term concerning the action of such a distinguished body as the Treasury Branch, to assume that Mr. Vannatter gets $100 per month for twelve months or that his salary exceeds $1,200 per year. We cannot, of course, assume that your Department is going to pay Mr. Vannatter $100 a month for twelve months because you have assured us that it is only for nine months. Will you, therefore, try to discover from the Treasury Branch why they have assumed that Mr. Vannatter's total income exceeds $1,200 a year? It certainly does not, so far as your Department is concerned.

The same thing applies to Mr. More.

We shall be glad if you will get the Treasury Branch to rectify this error, which no doubt has got into a number of others.

Every section of the instructions which I have read is to the effect that whilst all these taxes are collected month by month, they are based on the yearly income and the monthly computation is simply on the basis of usual practice of paying salaries in twelve monthly instalments, which is obviously not the case with your teachers.

Dear Sir:

Re: Your File 216-8-8274

With reference to your request of May 13th, for the names and ages, etc., of the Indians involved in the offences by Mr. R. R. Vannatter, ex-teacher of the Port Essington Indian Day School, I have to say they are, Harold Bolton age 12, Ernest Wesley age 12, and Raymond Wesley age 8.

The above matter was first brought to my attention by a letter signed by Stephen Campbell and Ed. Bolton. This letter was received Saturday, May 2nd, and Monday May 4th, at Essington I contacted these men who gave me the names of the boys mentioned above, who could supply some information, also the names of the following girls: Mildred Bennett age 8, Dorothy McKay age 11 and Irene Bolton age 14. I was convinced that Mr. Vannatter had done some wrong, so went directly to him and he admitted his wrong doing, as reported in my letter of May 5th. He absolutely denied, and stated that he was prepared to take oath to the effect that he had not molested the girls in any way whatever. I gathered from him that his misbehaviour had been going on at various times for at least two months.

Irene Bolton and Dorothy McKay were not at Essington on May 4th, but I interviewed the mother of the 8 year old girl and found her statements to be somewhat confused. I called on the Provincial Police and they informed me that they had made certain investigations and that their findings had not been corroborative, and that they intended to investigate the case further. As Mr. Vannatter had admitted his guilt to me, and as the matter was in the hands of the Police I considered that it was not necessary for me to go further in the affair. The Police expressed the opinion that a charge could not be laid under Section 206 of the Criminal Code, but that it could be dealt with under the Act as contributing to juvenile delinquency.

I have been informed since, that the Police now have evidence which makes it possible to lay information under Section 206 of the Criminal Code, but this does not involve any of our Indian Day School students.

Mr. Vannatter took charge of the Port Essington Day School October last. I visited the school on October 30th,
and found that he had good control over the children. I called on him December 23rd, and found him keenly interested in his school work. I visited this school again on February 27th, and everything was in order and the children appeared keenly interested in their work and good progress was noted among the scholars. Up to within a month of the complaint received against Mr. Vannatter, I had always received good reports concerning him from the people of Port Hastings.

Trusting I have fully covered your requirements in the above case, I am,

Yours faithfully,

J.G.

Res: Port Essington School.

On April 8th I visited the Port Essington Provincial School in the company of Mr. Indian Agent Anfield and Inspector E. Hyndman of the Provincial Department of Education.

There was 38 pupils on the roll, all of whom were of Indian or mixed origin. Of this number, there were 18 of Indian status, one of whom was absent due to illness.

There was a very happy atmosphere in the classroom and the pupils appeared to be making excellent progress. Last year separate schools were in operation at this point and I was fortunate in being able to compare attendance records for this year with that of last and previous years. The improvement in this respect was most striking. In the corresponding week last year, the number of Indian pupils attending our school was 7 and on going back through the register to the 1944-45 academic year, I noted that for no quarter did the average attendance of our pupils reach 14 although as many as 22 had been enrolled. In the present year, the average attendance has been well over 90%.

The attendance has so far exceeded our expectations and the Provincial authorities find it necessary to operate another room next year.

**CANADA**
Ottawa, January 20, 1930.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 10th instant, informing the Department of the appointment of Mrs. Elizabeth Pogson as teacher of the Port Essington Indian Day School to succeed Miss Dorothy Dean whose resignation took effect at the end of December, last. The qualifications which Mrs. Pogson possesses have been noted and are satisfactory. It is also noted that by making this appointment the school work is being continued without a break. The Department approves of the appointment of Mrs. Pogson, with salary at the rate of $100 per teaching month, and the authorities of the United Church of Canada are being informed of her appointment. It is hoped that she will meet with every success in the work at this school.

Relative to the request to supply fuel and light, I have to say that you may arrange to furnish the quantity of fuel required, and you should obtain same at the lowest possible cost. The Department, however, considers that the teacher should provide her own lighting. I may say that the supplying of fuel is to be continued only during the period Mrs. Pogson teaches at this school. If, in the future, the services of a single teacher are engaged she would, no doubt, be able to obtain boarding accommodation as in the past. In such case, the supplying of fuel would not be allowed. You should forward a properly certified voucher covering the expenditure incurred in the purchase of the fuel supplied Mrs. Pogson.

You might inform the Department whether Mr. Pogson, who, it is noted, is an invalid, will reside on the Reserve with his wife, as the Department does not desire, unless in exceptional cases, that a man having no duties in connection with Indian work live on a Reserve.

Your obedient servant,

W. E. Collison, Esq.,

Prince Rupert,

Ottawa, March 16, 1931.

Sir:

Relative to the extra single school desks asked for by the teacher of the Port Essington Indian Day School on her requisition forwarded under cover of your letter 3-D-3477 of the 3rd instant, I have to request that you will state the name of the manufacturer of the desks at present in use in this school. This information will, no doubt, be stamped on the metal parts of the desks, and is required in order to have uniformity in the seating arrangements if new desks are supplied. Full shipping directions should also be stated.

Our funds for the next fiscal year are extremely limited, and I should like to have your views as to whether these extra desks are necessary at the present time to provide seating accommodation for the children who attend. When we have your reply, consideration will then be given to the ordering of the desks.

Your obedient servant,

Secretary.

Dear Sir:

Your letter of the 23rd ultimo together with copies of correspondence as stated with reference to the proposed water supply at the Port Essington day school, is acknowledged.

I have consulted with Mr. H.W. Harris who looks after the water supply system at Port Essington. Mr. Harris tells me that on occasions when extreme frost occurs they find it necessary to shut off the water supply in order to protect the system. For this reason this point must be brought out in any suggested water rental.

The company will install at their expense, a 3/4" galvanized pipeline from their main to the school house, with one tap, at an annual rental service of $10.00, which I consider to be very reasonable and would suggest that the Indian Department avail themselves of the offer. The water supply comes by a wood stave pipe a distance of some two miles through rocky muskag country. The pipeline is only buried in places. The expense of covering the whole system has, I understand, not been considered economically feasible. The company will cover the 3/4" pipeline if it is in soil. If over rock they cannot guarantee this. However, the Indian Department will receive the same service as any other water users from this system, and it is only on rare occasions I am told, that the water supply is shut off.

I trust the above information will cover your requirements and will no doubt satisfy the department as to the reasonableness of the water company's offer of a water service.

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF G. H. BARRY, INSPECTOR OF INDIAN SCHOOLS, on his inspection of the PORT ESSINGTON Indian Day School - forwarded under cover of letter from C. C. Perry, Asst. Indian Commissioner, His No. 15/40032 of June 10, 1935.

The buildings consist of a schoolroom and a toilet, the latter having been constructed about two years ago. As mentioned in my last report, a very destructive fire occurred in the village about a year and a half ago, the United Church Mission house and Church being destroyed, as well as part of the old board walk to the school. A new church has now been built but its location is rather nearer to the school than takes in the place of the old board walk. A new walk is necessary for the school and the toilet should certainly be moved back from its present very prominent position close to the wall of the new church and placed at a position to the back of the school or well on one side away from the church. There is a pipe line to the school from which water is now obtained. The schoolroom should be painted inside and outside at the first opportunity. The buildings belong to the Department of Indian Affairs.

Three dozen screw hooks for the hanging of children's coats are very badly required at this school. Coats were lying all over the place when I visited the school.

The following single school desks are needed, and I should recommend the usual Crown Single School Desks, made in B. C. For the information of the Department, the quantity required and sizes are as follows:

One front section Number 2 One front section Number 3
Two Desk sections Number 2 Four Desk sections Number 3
One Rear Section Number 2 One Rear Section Number 3

This matter has not been discussed with the Indian Agent, who should, of course, be asked for a report before such desks are supplied.
Ottawa, June 20, 1935.

Sir:

Mr. Inspector Barry, in a report on his recent inspection of the Port Essington Indian Day School, recommends that a new board walk be installed, to replace the walk which was destroyed by fire at the time the mission house and church were burnt. He states, also, that the toilet should be moved back from its present very prominent position and placed at the back of the school or well to one side, away from the church. He has recommended, further, that the inside and outside of the school building be painted when funds are available.

I have to request that you will submit an estimate of the cost of material and labour in rebuilding the board walk and also the cost of moving the toilet to another site and placing it in a good, sanitary condition. You might state, also, the cost of the material and labour to paint the inside and outside of the school building. We may have no funds this year to carry out the painting, but same will be noted for our Estimates for next year. When information is received regarding the cost involved in the building of the walk and the moving of the toilet, consideration will be given to authorizing the expenditure required.

I have to request that you will arrange for the purchase and installation of three dozen coat hooks for the hanging of the children's coats. The Inspector states when he visited the school the children's coats were lying all over the place. Please forward an account, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the cost of supplying and installing the hooks.

The Inspector states, further, that a number of

W. E. Collison, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Prince Rupert, B. C.
single school desks be supplied. He recommends the Crown single school desk. You might state if you could arrange for the purchase, if you receive authority, or if you would prefer the order being placed here. In the latter event, I would request that you give full shipping directions.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.
Sir:

I shall be glad to receive authority to have the following repairs and improvements carried out in connection with the Port Essington Day school.

At the time of the fire last year which wiped out the village church and mission house, the plank walk to the school was totally destroyed and will need replacing for a distance of 165 feet over swampy ground.

The present school toilet should also be moved to a new location at the back of the school as it now stands too close to the church and is proving to be a nuisance. This situation was brought about by the fact that the new church was built a little nearer to the school than formerly and although it is not entirely incumbent upon the Department to bear the expense of moving the toilet, under the circumstances I would recommend that the work be done.

The floor and walls of the classroom should be painted.

The following is an estimate of the approximate cost of the improvements recommended,

School plank walk, 165' x 3'

- 2075 ft. lumber @ $22.00 per M. 45.65.
- 40 lbs. nails 4.00.
- Labour 25.00.
- Freight chgs. 6.00. $80.65.

Moving school toilet.

Labour and digging new pit. 25.00.

Painting floor and walls classroom.

- 2412 sq. ft. 8 gals @ $5.00, 40.00.
- Labour 12.00.
- 2 paint brushes @ 75¢ 1.50. 53.50.
- Total cost. $59.15.

Your obedient servant,

W.E. Collison,
Indian Agent.

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B. C., Vancouver.

The school stove at Port Essington will have to be replaced, and it is recommended that a no. 715 or 815 duo therm oil heater, whichever is available, be purchased immediately through McLennan, McFeely & Prior Ltd.

The present stove is just a small wood heater secured gratis from the War Assets Corporation this spring to replace the old stove which had fallen to pieces. This present stove burns wood only and is totally unsuitable for the size of the school.

In addition to this, it has been impossible to get any Indians at Port Essington to cut fuel wood this summer. Price of wood is out of all proportion even if one could get Indians to cut it. If we are going to retain Mrs. Pogson as teacher at Port Essington, it is imperative that an oil heater be installed at once, and it is recommended that this equipment be shipped direct to Port Essington Indian Day School and the accounts forwarded to this office for vouchering. I understand from the local representative of McLennan, McFeely & Prior Ltd. that the larger of the two oil burners will cost $105.00 approximately. If the purchase is made immediately, I can arrange for the winter's supply of oil to be delivered at Port Essington before the fuel barge leaves that fishing centre. This fuel would be paid for from funds on hand for wood.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Agent.

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B. C., Vancouver.

Res: Port Essington Indian Day School.

The Department sanctioned the sum of $204.00 for repairs to this School under date of May 29th, 1946, file 168-6-5, your file 215-8-4110 of June 3rd, 1946.

To date, expenditure has been as follows:

Labor $57.00 - Materials $56.94 - Total $113.94. This leaves a balance of $80.06.

An oil burner has been installed at this School and it will not be necessary to rebuild the woodshed.

The ceiling of this School is dried out and a large part of the heat is escaping into the attic.

It is recommended that this ceiling be lined with Donnaconda Board during the Christmas vacation.

Material required - 700 sq. ft. Donnaconda Board @ $82.50 per M. sq. ft. $57.75.

This material is immediately available from Philpott, Evitt & Co., Prince Rupert, and a Purchase Order to cover same is requested. Labor can be paid from the balance of the vote sanctioned and an accountable advance of $80.06 is requested to cover these labor costs, which will include the cost of painting the floor, nails, paint, etc.

This means an additional expenditure of $57.75 to the sum of $204.00 already sanctioned.

F. Earl Anfield.
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

I am forwarding Mr. Indian Agent Anfield's letter of November 29th in connection with further improvements required at the Fort Essington Indian Day School.

It will be noted that there is a balance of $80.06 of the sum of $204.00 authorized by the Department for repairs to this school, reference Mr. Phelan's letter 168-6-5 of May 29th, and that if funds to the further extent of $57.75 can be made available the ceiling of the building can be lined with Donnaconna board. Donnaconna is a good insulating material and it is thought that the expenditure would be justified. If funds are available it is recommended that an accountable advance of $80.06 be forwarded to Mr. Anfield, the balance of the $204.00 previously authorized, and that authority be granted for the purchase of the Donnaconna board at a cost of $57.75.

Re attached copies of correspondence received today from Prince Rupert District School Board.

The situation at Port Essington is as follows:

The attendance requires a two room classroom, the old second classroom belonging to the school board was unsafe and has been destroyed. The Indian Day School building temporarily used by the school board as a second classroom is unsuitable to the needs of the board. It is slowly collapsing and is in poor physical condition. The board do not consider favourable any attempt to repair this building. They have therefore bought a new building which will become the second classroom, at Port Essington. The attendance of this school of native children has been highly satisfactory and the entire experiment of co-education of white and native children is an accomplishment in co-operation. The board asked the assistance of the Department in providing new classroom and from every point of view, I have no hesitation in recommending that an outright grant of $1500 be made towards the capital cost of this new plan. If the school board were at this time to discontinue the present arrangement, we would be faced with an expenditure of at least a thousand dollars to repair and renovate the old Indian Day School which if my memory is correct, is over 40 years old.

I wrote you under date of August 23rd in connection with a request from Prince Rupert School District No. 52 for a contribution of $1500 towards the cost of providing a second classroom at Port Essington, the necessity for which was occasioned by the enrolment of Indian pupils. Apparently no reply was received to my letter and Supt. Anfield has again raised the question, reference his letter of December 19th and enclosures attached.

You will note that the cost of the building to the School District was $2,508.31, and that the total enrolment is comprised of 22 Indian pupils and 27 white pupils. The single classroom owned by the School District prior to the arrangement for the joint education of white and Indian pupils would have been sufficient to meet the needs of the available white pupils and consequently it is felt that the School District's request for a grant of $1500 towards a second classroom is reasonable. Re: Port Essington School
Prince Rupert School Dist. #52

Attached please find application of the above-noted School Board for an outright grant of $1500.00 towards the purchase and furnishing of a second classroom at Port Essington where we have 22 Indian pupils attending elementary school on a per capita basis in the school administered by the Prince Rupert District School Board. At present there are 27 pupils (white) attending the school, a total pupilage of 49 children.

During the first year that Indian children were accommodated in this per capita basis, we had approximately 17 pupils attending. In the second year this number increased to the place where a second classroom was necessary. We placed the former Indian Day School, built in between the years 1909 and 1912 at their disposal. This building was in such condition that extensive repairs would be required to make it suitable for continued use. The Board also felt that they were not justified in putting provincial tax-payers funds into a federally owned building on an Indian Reserve. They therefore negotiated for and purchased a building (formerly the R.C. Chapel and residence) adjacent to the one room white school and have made it into a second classroom.

The Board asked for capital assistance towards the purchase and adoption of this building for school purposes on the grounds that they would have no need for the extra building if they were not educating out Indian children.

Actually, we are getting off easy in this matter as the Board might have considered we should pay the whole cost of the second classroom. They have consistently co-operated in joint
education for whites and Indians.

I have therefore, no hesitation in recommending once more, an immediate grant of $1500.00 towards this building and your early advice will be appreciated.

It might be said that if the grant is refused, we may be asked to discontinue the present arrangement, following which we would have to immediately construct a one room school and teacherage at Port Essington, the cost of which should not be less than that at Metlakatla.

I would refer you to my correspondence in this application, under date of August 16/49.

Re: Port Essington School.

On April 8th I visited the Port Essington Provincial School in the company of Mr. Indian Agent Anfield and Inspector L. Hyndman of the Provincial Department of Education.

There were 38 pupils on the roll, all of whom were of Indian or mixed origin. Of this number, there were 13 of Indian status, one of whom was absent due to illness.

There was a very happy atmosphere in the class room and the pupils appeared to be making excellent progress. Last year separate schools were in operation at this point and I was fortunate in being able to compare attendance records for this year with that of last and previous years. The improvement in this respect was most striking. In the corresponding week last year, the number of Indian pupils attending our school was 7 and on going back through the register to the 1944-45 academic year, I noted that for no quarter did the average attendance of our pupils reach 14 although as many as 22 had been enrolled. In the present year, the average attendance has been well over 90%.

The attendance has so far exceeded our expectations and the Provincial authorities find it necessary to operate another room next year.

Report on Port Essington Indian Day School

The average attendance at the school has slightly increased. The drop in the attendance for the quarters ending December 1935 and March 1936 is due to the fact that some ten children attending the school are not shown on the Roll of the school after September 1935. The average attendance has been as shown below:

Attendance for Quarter ending:

| Quarter       | Year | Attendance |
|---------------|------|------------|
| September     | 1934 | 22.60      |
| December      | 1934 | 21.67      |
| March         | 1935 | 32.80      |
| June          | 1935 | 28.47      |
| September     | 1935 | 28.45      |
| December      | 1935 | 19.85      |
| March         | 1936 | 19.45      |
| June          | 1936 | ?          |

The real average attendance for the quarters ending December 1935 and March 1936 was some 10 greater than shown above. The 10 children who can not be considered as Indians within the meaning of the Indian Act were taken off the Register by the teacher on instructions of Mr. Indian Agent Collison.

There is not sufficient seating accommodation for the Indian children and the extra 10 children now attending this school. In addition the teacher is not able to teach all the children with success. The standard of the work is thus falling, and nothing that I can do will improve matters.

I have therefore to recommend that the ten children at present attending this school who are not Indians, and this includes the teacher's own little girl, be EXCLUDED FROM THE INDIAN DAY SCHOOL. I understand that they will be admitted to the local Provincial Day School which is located within a few hundred yards. I also understand that this is the wish of the Provincial Inspector of Schools for this District that these children be sent to the Provincial School. I agree with him in every way.

I would ask that definite instructions be sent to the Indian Agent, Mr. W.E.Collison, to instruct the teacher Mrs. Pogson, to exclude all children who are not Indians from the Port Essington Indian Day School. This will make the provision of new single desks less necessary and give the teacher a chance to pull up the general standard of the work in the Primary Grades.

General Remarks:

There is little that I need add to the above. While the work of the Primary Grades is at present most unsatisfactory, it would be possible to greatly improve this if there were less children in the school, or if the teacher were younger and more efficient.

As I am not anxious to recommend that a new teacher be appointed here at the present time, I have taken the only remaining course and recommended a reduction in the number of children to be taught. The children who attend the school while living on the Indian Reserve though not Indians belong to two families. There are good reasons I understand why these particular families should be allowed to live on the Indian Reserve. The child of the teacher is falling back in her work and I consider she too should attend the Provincial School, and be taught by someone other than her mother.

No doubt the Department will wish for a full report, on the matters mentioned above, from the Indian Agent. I may say that these matters have been discussed with Mr. Indian Agent Collison on several occasions during the past two years, and I believe we are in complete agreement with regard to the necessity for the exclusion of the NON INDIAN CHILDREN in this case without laying down any general rule which must be followed in all such cases.

INSPECTOR'S REPORT ON PORT ESSINGTON INDIAN DAY SCHOOL

Skeena River Agency.

Date of inspection: May 1st 1936.

Number of pupils present: 4 Boys and 13 Girls; Total 17

There were also present 2 Boys and 8 Girls who are not on the Roll of the school. These pupils are mentioned later in this report. They are included here as the actual number of children inspected was 27, made up of 6 Boys and 21 Girls.

Number of classrooms: One.

Number of desks in each classroom: 6 Single and 13 old Double.

Name of teacher: Mrs. Elizabeth Pogson, Age 54.

Health: The teacher's health is reported to be "Good".

Remarks relative to methods employed by teacher:

Mrs. Pogson was trained at the Winnipeg Normal School. She holds Second Class Permanent Certificates in Manitoba and British Columbia. She also holds an Ontario Second Class (Non Professional) Certificate. Mrs Pogson has had eight years experience in Provincial schools and seven years in Indian schools.

In my last report I mentioned that the teacher had made a great effort to improve the standing of her school. During the past year I am sorry to say this improved standing has not been maintained. The teachers work with the Primary pupils in Grade IA and Grade IB is not in my opinion satisfactory. Some of the children were absent however and I am therefore not stressing the teacher's obvious weakness in the teaching of the primary at the present time.

One of the Grade 6 pupils seen on the occasion of my visit in May 1935 passed the High School Entrance Test in June 1935 with the minimum mark of 60%. This boy is I understand doing good work in the Prince Rupert High School.

Much more thorough teaching is necessary in the Intermediate and Senior Grades. The results of the Achievement Tests given during this last visit indicate that the teacher has neglected to make certain that the lessons, if properly taught, were understood.

There is a very definite reason for the failure of the children during the past year. There are too many children for this rather elderly teacher. Suggestions are made below to eliminate this difficulty. It will also be understood that I have done everything possible to help the teacher with regard to methods, etc. She is however rather too old to make much use of my "Demonstration and Type Lessons". Her knowledge of the Psychology of Teaching is in my opinion very limited, hence she does not get the best results, and her pupils suffer. Mrs Pogson is nearing the end of her teaching career, and I am afraid that it will not be very long before she forces me to ask the Department to make a change of teachers here. I think that a letter from the Department to this teacher stating that her work has not been considered very satisfactory during the past year by the Inspector of Schools might result in some improvement in the work.

Remarks relative to the examination of pupils:

Reading: Some of the children in this Grade have been here over a year, one or more have been here three years. I am informed by the teacher, Grade 1B have finished Two Little Indians and are at Page 57 of Friends. The reading was very elementary word for word, and far below the usual standard of the Indian Day School for this Sub Grade. Grade 2 has finished Friends and are at Page 106 of the Highroads Reader Book 1. One of the children off the Roll of the School could read this well. Grade 2 read quite well the first half of Highroads Reader Book 2. The Grade 3 pupil read well from Highroads Reader Book 3. Grade 5 read in a very satisfactory manner from Highroads Reader Book 5, but they are very weak in the meanings of the harder words. Grade 6 was absent and Grade 7 reads from Voice of Canada, Lady of the Lake, Etc. The reading of Grade 1 is very unsatisfactory while the remaining children present read well.

Arithmetic: Grade 1B have only a very limited knowledge of the Combinations and Separations to 10. Grade 1A are supposed to be able to work the Combinations and Separations to 20 according to the statement of the teacher. The only child that had no idea of this work. Grade 2 can Add and Subtract with and without carrying and Borrowing. Grade 3 can work Short Multiplication and Short Division, and know the Multiplication Tables to times 12. Grade 5 know something of the work in Fractions and are starting Decimals, while Grade 7 is working the prescribed course. The actual work done by Grades 2, 3, and 5, in Arithmetic is a little below average, while Grade 7 is well up to the average. In the All Canada Test:-
Grade 3 made a Mid Score of 12.5 the Norm being 13.6
Grade 4 made a Mid Score of 20.5 the Norm being 27.0
Grade 7 made a Mid Score of 36.5 the Norm being 35.4

The idea of SUBTRACTION is not yet thoroughly in school. Paper after paper showed that the children did not understand the usual signs used in Arithmetic, and particularly could not recognize or work questions involving the subtraction of numbers. This was of course pointed out to the pupils and a short lesson taught to remedy this failure as far as possible.

Geography: The B.C. Geography for Juniors is used. More definite lessons are needed throughout the school.

History: Pages from Canada's Story is used in Grade 5.

Writing: This is very uneven. While some pupils can write quite well others are very poor in this.

Art: Very elementary work has been done.

Spelling: The Spelling in Grade 2 was "Poor" while that of the remainder of the school was "Good". The usual Buckingham Achievement Scale was used. Grades 2 & 3 being given 25 words from Columns "I" & "J", while Grades 4 & 7 were given 25 words from Columns "Q" & "R". The following were the results:
Grade 2 made a Mid Score of 58% the June Norm being 70%
Grade 3 made a Mid Score of 100% the June Norm being 86%
Grade 5 made a Mid Score of 90% the June Norm being only 70%
Grade 7 made a Mid Score of 98% the June Norm being 90%

Singing: While the teacher is not able to sing herself the children sang nicely with good tone, hymns, Etc.

General School Work: The standard of achievement in the various school subjects in general was tested by the B.C. Achievement Test for Juniors 1934 for Grades 3 and 5 and by the B.C. Achievement Test 1933 for Grade 7. Grade 3 made a Mid Score of 8, the Norm and expected score 18.3
Grade 5 made a Mid Score of 27.5 the Norm being 35.2
Grade 7 made a Mid Score of 50.5 the Norm being 62.6

The above results are low but fairly satisfactory. The great weakness of the school being the work of Grade 1. There has however been a very great falling off in the general achievement results since the last inspection, when the tested work of the pupils was "Very Satisfactory".

The real average attendance for the quarters ending December 1935 and March 1936 was some 10 greater than shown above. The 10 children who can not be considered as Indians within the meaning of the Indian Act were taken off the Register by the teacher on instructions of Mr. Indian Agent Collison.

There is not sufficient seating accommodation for the Indian children and the extra 10 children now attending this school. In addition the teacher is not able to teach all the children with success. The standard of the work is thus falling, and nothing that I can do will improve matters.

I have therefore to recommend that the ten children at present attending this school who are not Indians, and this includes the teacher's own little girl, be EXCLUDED FROM THE INDIAN DAY SCHOOL. I understand that they will be admitted to the local Provincial Day School which is located within a few hundred yards. I also understand that it is the wish of the Provincial Inspector of Schools for this District that these children be sent to the Provincial School. I agree with him in every way.

I would ask that definite instructions be sent to the Indian Agent, Mr. W.E.Collison, to instruct the teacher Mrs. Pogson, to exclude all children who are not Indians from the Port Essington Indian Day School. This will make the provision of new single desks less necessary and give the teacher a chance to pull up the general standard of the work in the Primary Grades.

General Remarks:

There is little that I need add to the above. While the work of the Primary Grades is at present most unsatisfactory, it would be possible to greatly improve this if there were less children in the school, or if the teacher were younger and more efficient.

As I am not anxious to recommend that a new teacher be appointed here at the present time, I have taken the only remaining course and recommended a reduction in the number of children to be taught. The children who attend the school while living on the Indian Reserve though not Indians belong to two families. There are good reasons I understand why these particular families should be allowed to remain on the Indian Reserve. The child of the teacher is falling back in her work and I consider she too should attend the Provincial School, and be taught by someone other than her mother.

No doubt the Department will wish for a full report on the matters mentioned above, from the Indian Agent. I may say that these matters have been discussed with Mr. Indian Agent Collison on several occasions during the past two years, and I believe we are in complete agreement with regard to the necessity for the exclusion of the NON INDIAN CHILDREN in this case without laying down any general rule which must be followed in all such cases.

Remarks relative to the examination of pupils:

As only six pupils were present it is not easy to be perfectly fair in these remarks.

In general the children read quite well. Grades 5 and 4 are reading Highroad Readers which they read last year. Grade 4 is well able to go to Grade 5. Grade IA in Highroad Reader Book 1 and Grade LC from the Board read quite well. One little boy while a pupil of this school for several years does not appear to be able to distinguish words. The teacher will take special care in this case, and if possible discover the cause of failure.

The Number Work and Arithmetic is not as good as the Reading in any Grade tested.

The small children still count their Addition Facts and Subtraction Facts. I have shown the type of Drills necessary to remedy this.

All the writing is in pencil so far. The teacher tells me that he has just received the ink exercise books and that the pupils will use ink where this is required in future. The small children must certainly learn to print and write in the pencil exercise books and not only work on the Boards.

In Language the teacher appears to have carried out suggestions made for the teaching of Oral Composition in Grade 1. These suggestions were given to him when he called at my office in Victoria before coming to Port Essington. Grades 4 and 5 are using the English Usage and Work Books properly. Grade 4 will now join Grade 5.

The Elementary Geography is being taught in accordance with suggestions previously made to the teacher. The Built Up Panel Posters will now be used properly, which has not been the case in the past here.

The pages from Canada's story will be used as a test in Grades 4 and 5 for Canadian History.

I have suggested a course in Elementary Science which now takes the place of Nature.

Quite good work has been done in Art and Handwork by the little people.

Some attempt is being made to teach Singing.

In general the teaching so far is very elementary, and far too much time has been given to so-called testing. I have urged the teacher to make a start in definite lessons in the various subjects.

Control of the children is "Fair".

Attendance problem: remedies suggested, etc.

Only Indian children attend this school now. The children of John Wesley, MAILE Age 19, RITA Age 8, GILBERT Age 10, and DOUGLAS Age 9 do not attend regularly. The teacher has called on the parents and the Indian Agent is aware of the circumstances. The father should be warned to send his children regularly to this school and I would ask that a check be kept on this matter.

In the case of SILAS INNES Age 12 Grade 4 and ROY INNES Age 9 Grade IA the home conditions are stated to be very bad. The father is dead and the mother drinks, is often in Prince Rupert and neglects the children.

Should these children be found fit from a medical point of view I strongly recommend that they be sent to Coqualeetza Indian Residential School as soon as possible. I know that there is room there for them.

Dear Major MacKay:

I am forwarding herewith my report on the Port Essington Indian Day School, Skeena River Agency.

This school was inspected this morning, October 28th. I was accompanied by Mr. Indian Agent Collison. The weather is very bad indeed. We started from Prince Rupert in the launch "Naskena" at dawn and were very lucky to be able to get to Port Essington and back in the day. The storms are now so bad that any more launch work this season is just a matter of waiting for a suitable day. After my visit to the newly erected school at Kitselas early next week, I propose to return to Vancouver. I shall probably go south on the Canadian National S.S. Prince Rupert sailing from here on Thursday evening, November 4th. This will enable me to be in my office in Vancouver on Monday morning, November 8th, when I hope to have the opportunity to discuss with you the more important items of interest brought to my attention during the present itinerary. You may of course be out of the city at that time and in this case such discussion can well be postponed to suit your convenience.

Even if not strong these children would in my opinion be better off at Coqualeetza than in Port Essington.

There has been some friction between the teacher Mr Rutherford, who is also the United Church Missionary, and the Catholic Priest with regard to some of the boys attending games with other children off the Indian Reserve, such games and/or classes being organized by the Priest, Reverend Father Champlain.

I explained to Mr Rutherford that as far as his position as a teacher was concerned it would be better for him to pay little attention to the fact that the Indian boys mixed with others in the Port Essington village though as a United Church Missionary he had a perfect right to give his congregation any advice he thought right. Mr Collison and I had previously seen the Catholic Priest who stated that he had no wish to draw the United Church children away from the school, and could not prohibit them taking part in games etc. with other boys from the village, if they wished to visit his hall. It will be understood that there are a number of churches working in Port Essington. As a result of our visit to the Priest and teacher better relations between them should result.

Yours very truly,

With reference to Mr. Inspector Thorsteinsson's report on Port Essington School relative to attendance, I would say that according to Mrs. Pogson, she had no difficulty in having the children attend school when they were at the village, but they move around considerably with their parents to logging camps and fishing grounds. I do not know of any steps that can be taken to remedy the matter, other than some scheme whereby one family would board another's children when the parents have to leave the village. I have suggested this many times in the various villages, but some of the parties concerned who are well able to do this are not sufficiently interested to spend any money for the education of their children, and those who would be in a position to take children would not trust one of their own people with reference to payment.

J. Gillett,
Indian Agent.

Further to my letter of January 17th forwarding Provincial School Inspector Thorsteinson's report covering his inspection of Fort Essington Indian Day School, I now enclose herewith for your information Mr. Indian Agent Gillett's letter of January 23rd outlining the difficulties encountered in maintaining the attendance at this school.

It would appear that in view of the excellent opportunities offered the Indians for employment at various points nothing much can be done while this continues to keep them in their villages and thus ensure the attendance of the children at the school. However the enforcement of Sub. Sec. 2 of Section 4 of the Family Allowances Act should do much to remedy this situation.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Very good effort being put forth - control good. Repairs have made real improvement to School.

Mrs. Pogson is doing good work at this School. Control is good and the children are bright and exceptionally clean and tidy. The efforts of teacher and pupils are worthwhile and if only the children would attend regularly, they could go far.

The school was clean and neat and the repairs to stoves and ceiling have made it, as Mrs. Pogson states, "the most warm and comfortable she has even known it".

Mrs. Pogson who has taught at Essington for nearly 14 years will not be returning next fall. Since the death of her husband, who was Postmaster at Port Essington for many yrs., she has a desire to leave the place and has only carried on the school out of loyalty. This has been a dreadfully cold and severe winter and she does not think her health will stand any more. She is far from young and I would pay tribute to her efforts. It is a happy little school, progressive and well conducted.

Dear Sir:

Re the question of "accommodation for teacher," it was found rather unsatisfactory.

I came here at New Years' time and rented an unfurnished flat. After living in it for three months, I received notice unexpectedly to vacate the rooms. Another person had rented the whole house.

The only available house in town is one owned by an Indian. This one needs some repair in order to make it habitable. Two weeks ago I wrote to the Indian Agent asking if he was willing that we should have this.

I have not received an answer; nothing has been done to the house and I have to move into it at the Easter vacation. I have to
I am very anxious and concerned about the house and do not know how to keep it in good condition. The owner will not let me make any repairs. Moreover, I cannot live there in winter unless it is made warmer.

In many other districts there is a teacher's residence. Would it be possible to buy or build one here? As my husband's health is poor, I should like to remain for some time. I find the work very interesting and have already become attached to the pupils; but the housing problem presents a very serious difficulty.

Will you kindly take the matter up with the proper authorities and ascertain whether something can be done about it.

Trusting that you may be able to accomplish this,

Yours respectfully,

Elizabeth Roy

Ottawa, May 7th, 1930.

Madam:

I have your letter of the 14th ultimo, enclosing your annual report on the Port Essington Indian Day School for the fiscal year ended March 31st last, and requesting that a residence be provided for the teacher's use at this school.

In reply I have to say that previous to your appointment unmarried teachers were employed at this school, and they were able to obtain suitable board and living accommodation, and there was, therefore, no necessity to provide a teacher's residence. Our funds for the present fiscal year are extremely limited, and it will not be possible to consider the erection of a residence. It is hoped that you can make arrangements to obtain suitable living accommodation. It should be possible to have the Indian owner of the house in which you at present reside carry out certain repairs and improvements in order to make it comfortable.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Mrs. Elizabeth Pogson,
Teacher, Indian Day School,
Port Essington, B.C.

Rev. Sir,

The Department is in receipt of Mr. Inspector Green's report on the Fort Simpson Day School, which shows a very small attendance, there being only fourteen present out of 150 children of school age in the village. The explanation for this unsatisfactory attendance is that the Teacher, who is a member of the boarding school staff, has his time so fully occupied that he is unable to secure a proper attendance by visiting and becoming acquainted with the Indian parents and pupils.

The Indians wish to have a teacher who shall devote his whole time to the day school, and as the Department pays a salary it considers that they should have one. Mr. Demeane would be willing to accept the position of teacher to the day school, and the Department thinks that he should be given charge of the school and that he should sever his connection with the boarding school, so as to be free to devote the whole of his time to the betterment of the villagers and their children. It is hardly fair that the interests of the 150 children should be sacrificed for the 20 children who are in the boarding school.

Sir:

Replying to your letter No II9542/I, dated June 23rd, ultimo, in which you ask for a report upon existing school arrangements, and a few suggestions as to the betterment of such.

As you will judge from the reports of both teacher and Agent from time to time, conditions are far from being satisfactory at the present time.

For some time I was of opinion that if the money now spent on the maintenance of Boarding Schools were applied to the creation of efficiently equipped Indian Day schools with a public school system and fully qualified teachers, the difficulty would be removed; but having thought the matter carefully over, and taken into consideration the nomadic habits of the people—their being at their home village only about three months of the year—the impracticality of trying to effect an arrangement whereby the children could follow up their studies in different schools as they moved from place to place with their parents in pursuit of their occupations—the non-enactment of compulsory attendance regulations, being the policy of the Department to rely upon the mission of its officers, teachers and missionaries, to overcome the apathy of the Indians—I have almost come to the conclusion that the idea of the Day school system is a psychological absurdity.

At the same time I am convinced that the Boys' Home, Port Simpson, is an institution which stands for very little in view of the amount spent each year by the Department and the Methodist Church, for its maintenance. Boys are allowed to go to their homes and to the canneries during the summer months, and as soon as the season is over when the lads should return to the institution, they are
conspicuous by their absence, and parents lay unfounded charges of harsh treatment, starving, peisinging etc., against the workers of the institution.

The fact of the matter is that the Indians have been the subjects of superfluous fending the lavishment of which, by coaxing, effeminate handling with presents and soft speech, which geads rather than aids the Indian nature, and which the Indian does not look for, the result of which is that the Indians have been made to feel that the white people are under some form of obligation to them, and they now manifest a decided indifference to the methods adopted to educate them.

The Indians have a great respect for the law when they see it carried into effect, and the success of William Duncan among the new Alaskan Indians is a proof of this.

At the various Council meetings of the Indians I am asked to enforce the law, to make regulations and see that such are carried into effect, whether in relation to schools or the Indian Act, or the By-laws of the villages.

I am in favor of a thoroughly equipped Indian Day school, with up-to-date appliances, competent teachers with boarding arrangements; compulsory attendance for eight months of the year, and four months leave of absence during the fishing season.

Under the present arrangements the yearly pay of teacher is given for about three months work. I would appoint a fully qualified teacher at an extra hundred dollars per ### eight months, and give the teacher the opportunity of spending part of the season with the pupils at the canneries not for the purpose of teaching them but for the purpose of being near them to learn their experiences.

I would also suggest that the parents of the pupils be expected by the Department to contribute towards the keeping of the pupil by paying for their clothing, and their fare to and from the canneries. Up to the present this has been done by the Church.
Teaching Mr Dineen's work at Fort Simpson, there is no doubt but that he has too much in hand at present to do justice to either the school or the Home.

He makes a splendid head of the Institution, and has the boys well in hand. They are smart and industrious, and under his management would make good progress.

I would recommend that the Department spend a little money on painting, and in making the surroundings of the institution more homelike, or if this is the duty of the Church advise the Church to see to it, employ a good teacher as before intimated, issue a circular for distribution among the Indian parents showing how essential is the education of the children as they make physical progress towards the new conditions of civilization as they spring up on every side, and also the decision of the Department in the matter of compulsory attendance in the light of the similar regulations under which it is incumbent upon white people to send their children to school.

I think the Indians would fall into line with such a movement when it became apparent that it was being carried to a practical and successful issue.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

I very much regret to report that upon my calling in at Fort Simpson on my way South from the Nass, on the 5th instant, I found that while there are nearly 100 children of school age in the village, only two of them were at the school.

On the 23rd September a telegram reached me & from the Rev G.H. Raley, as follows:

"School matters Port Simpson require your attention earliest date important"

Being then about to start by steamer for the Nass, calling at Fort Simpson on the way North, I asked the Captain of the steamer to wait a little while in order to an interview with Mr. Raley. I met him, and talked the matter over. Mr. Raley was not prepared to give his opinion as to the reason of the poor attendance at the school, but appeared to suspect there may be some personal feeling against the teacher, Mr. Dine.

I asked Chief Dudoward, Chief Councillor why the people did not send their children to school, to which he replied "The people will tell you".

I afterwards met Chief Henry Nelson, and put the same question to him. He replied "The teachers we have up here are no good.

I called on Chief Kelly who, upon being questioned, said: "Sometimes I send my children to school, but they don't get on. I ask them when they come home what they learn, and they not know what to tell me. They don't bring home their books like white children."

In several instances I have heard the remark that the children are being killed in the Boy's and Girl's Homes, because through some hereditary taint they happen to die sometimes either...
after their release from the institutions.

For some time very unkind remarks have been made by the Indians about the association of the missionaries with the Church and Government for which a whiteman would have been incarcerated, but these have all been tolerated by them because they came from the Indians, which so far as it goes is quite right.

I may inform the Department that Mr Dineen, the present teacher has received another appointment in Manitoba, and leaves at an early date. I feel sure that when he has gone the Indians will feel the loss of one who has conscientiously done his very best for them, while the Boy's Home will lose one of the best Principals it has ever had. The fact that Mr Dineen is to be the Rev T. Ferrier's assistant at the Brandon Institute speaks for his integrity, worth as a disciplinarian and good character.

The Department is not ignorant of the condition of affairs at Fort Simpson, and has previously received my recommendations, which, according to your letter No II9542/I, dated August 12th last, are held in abeyance.

I would point out that during the past four years each appointment at this school has taken the form of a make-shift. Mr. Savage was first in charge of the school for a few months, and was dismissed by Rev. T. Ferrier, Supt. of Indian Education of the Methodist Church, for smoking. Next was Mr. Lionel Dineen, who taught for a short term, and afterwards left to take up work at Brandon, Manitoba. After his departure the school was in charge of a lad named Ramsley Haley, son of Rev. G.H. Raley for a little over 2 months.

The school was next conducted by Mr. Frank Moody, an ex-pupil of the Coqualeetza Institute at Chilliwack, B.C., for a little over 5 months. When he left, Miss Bland took charge whose term was very short. She was succeeded by Mr. L.M. Richardson who has now left after a term of about one year. Mr. Richardson has now left. No notice has been given of his intention to resign.

As this school is the largest on the agency, there being about 150 children of school age in the vicinity of the school, it is thought that the Methodist Church authorities should endeavour to do better for this school than they do in the matter of appointing teachers. The reason for the frequent changes would appear to be that the salary paid for services as teacher is inadequate, and in consequence there seems

seems to be a scarcity of teachers.

I am of opinion that the day has come when teachers should be both competent and sufficiently paid. Missionaries of the present day in British Columbia do not feel themselves called upon to make the sacrifices which were necessary fifty years ago. The country is rich, and environment is modern. The cost of living is high in the north, and teachers should not be expected to be competent masters of their profession and at the same time penurious in their mode of living.

Dear Sir,-

Replying to your request of the 24th. instant, re a teacher for the Port Simpson day school, I have noted carefully its contents. The policy proposed in this letter is next to an absolute impossibility. There are three classes of teachers that are available for a school of this kind. If a man is following the regular teaching profession and is absolutely no good as a teacher, you could get him to go to Port Simpson for $720.00. If he stands well in his profession he will simply laugh at you when you offer him that amount of money. To secure his services you would have to pay from fifteen hundred to two thousand a year. The third class we have to draw from are men who have the missionary spirit and who are either probationers in our church or offering themselves as such. Mr. Richardson was a probationer in the Methodist church, and a graduate of Victoria University. He accepted of the position for a year to help us out of the difficulty we were in. I went so far as to offer him what was equal to at least a thousand dollars for his services another year, but he felt that the time had come when he should take up his regular work of preaching. This necessitated the securing of another man, whom I think holds
a similar position in his relationship to the church. Upon this I am not quite positive, so I have written Mr. Raley this morning asking him for particulars. The Department will see from this the great difficulty in carrying out a policy such as is suggested in your letter. My own opinion is that the problem will not be solved until we have a plant for the boarding school suitable to meet all the needs of a place like Port Simpson, and in the meantime I trust that the former request that I made is provided for in the estimates. In view of the forthcoming nomination of a teacher to succeed Mr. G.H. Hamilton at the Fort Simpson Indian Day School by the Methodist Church authorities, I would beg to make a few observations:

(1). It is noticed that the Church invariably nominates a person who is a theological student, whose ambition is to enter the ministry. This being the case, the teacher is expected to undertake preaching and other duties in preparation for which time is occupied which should be devoted to school studies, and in looking after pupils. Particularly at Fort Simpson there are disadvantages noticed, as the local missionary as Chairman of the Simpson District of the Church travels considerably and his duties are undertaken by the resident teacher.

The student's term as teacher is short-lived; and in addition to this he has to leave his school in the charge of a supply whenever he goes to Prince Rupert to study seminary.

Mr. Hamilton, the present Teacher, has informed me that he finds the extra burden of work more than he should undertake, and agrees that his connection with Church duties is detrimental to the best interests of the school.

(2). It will have been noticed by the reports of this school from time to time that there are over one hundred children of school age in the vicinity of the school. The average attendance throughout the present and preceding years has been very poor in spite of the fact that the school is well equipped and in first-class condition.

The demand for compulsory attendance at this school would be beneficial has been anticipated by the Department in the appointment of the Dominion Constable, Mr. Watkinson, as Truant Officer.

The Department is paying for the services of a teacher at the rate of $56.00 per month, yet the Indians have an apparently settled idea that the school is operated under Church auspices and control and will not heed the frequent warnings given by the Truant Officer.

Sir,

The primary classes have in the past been conducted by Mrs. A. Budoward, wife of the late head Chieftain. While this lady has done her best, there is no indication that her efforts have in any measure helped to prepare the little ones for admission to the higher classes. Mrs. Budoward has abandoned this work, and now the classes are all together in the main class-room. For a time she appointed one of her sons to look after her duties, but he is entirely incompetent to undertake such duties.

No requisition has ever been made for kindergarten materials, nor are such made use of in the class-room.

In view of the foregoing observations, it has occurred to me that the Port Simpson Indian Lay School should be brought entirely under Government control, more particularly as the salary paid is equal to that paid other Government teachers. Nomination should be made by the Government or its officers and the Indians notified that in future the school will be a Government school, attendance at which when the Indians are at home will be compulsory, subject always to the provisions of the school regulations.

An additional experienced teacher should be appointed for the primary classes.

A place of residence for the use of teachers could be furnished, if desirable, placed at the teachers' disposal at a reasonable rental. In this way the teachers would not be thrown upon the hospitality of the Mission.

In the appointment of teachers as suggested, care should be taken to nominate persons who are of good mor-
Sir,

moral character, and who have certificates of qualification at least equal to those under which Provincial teachers are accepted under salary.

Sir,

Dear Sir,

Yours of a recent date to hand asking me be the efficiency of our Indian Day School.

I may say we have in charge of our school gifted teachers, with whom it is a pleasure to meet.

In other words he told them not to follow too closely the course of study laid down.

If need be take the children off on the beach or to the woods for rambles; anything to increase the attendance.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter re Indian day schools and in reply I wish to state that as regards the attendance and as far as I am concerned as truant officer I have done everything in my power to keep the attendance up.

I have talked to the school as truants five and some children at one time and I have had all kinds of trouble with the parents.

The Indian school cannot be compared with the White school as the Indians here are mostly all fishermen, they are here one day and away the next day and they will not leave their children in the village to go to school, as they have no interest whatsoever or do not at any time visit the school.

I am informed that Inspector Burns has given the teacher authority to use any means whatever to get the attendance, this in my opinion should not be, as strict discipline should be used, school opened on time and everything done to show the Indians that the teacher is doing his part and they had to do theirs; and then if they will not send their children to school either close the school or enforce the regulations string, these half measures with the Indians is poor policy as they will take advantage of you every chance they get, it is only those who are in close contact with them every day to know that this is true.

I am quite willing to do or work in writing anything that could be done for the benefit of the Indians.
There is at present about 15 children in the village and most of these will be going to the cannery tomorrow.

The toilets at the school are in a very unsanitary condition and should be attended to before the new term, also the side walk leading to the school is in very bad repair.

A good fence should also be provided for the school as the proper time be kept.

REMARKS.

This day school at Port Simpson is not satisfactory. We have had several teachers try to make a success of this school during the last five years. Some of them were Normal graduates but all have failed to get satisfactory results.

The school year is short and even when the people are in the Village it is almost impossible to get regular attendance. The parents are not interested. The home is not organized with the school in view.

There were nine present the day of my visit. Two were in the second reader and two were in the first reader. These four were making very good progress. They understand English. The remaining five were struggling with word recognition.

Another teacher will be put in as soon as attendance calls for it.

Miss Kate Tranter, teacher of the Indian day school at Port Simpson, B.C., has on account of ill-health applied for superannuation under the provisions of the Public Service Retirement Act 1920, as amended 1921, 1922 and 1923. Miss Tranter entered the service of this Department as teacher of the Fort Essington Indian Day School November 1, 1890, and has been teaching continuously since that time at Fort Essington, Bella Bella, and Port Simpson, respectively. The following details with reference to her retirement are available:

Age .................................................. 55 yrs.,
Date of last appointment ......................... Nov. 1, 1890,
Date of retirement ................................ July 1, 1924,
Length of service .................................. 33 yrs. 7 mos.
Present salary ....................................... $900,
Average salary for last 3 yrs. ................. $900,

Dear Sir,

I had a conversation with Miss Kate Tranter when I was out at Port Simpson in April. Her doctor had written me previous to this stating her health was very poor and that she ought to be relieved of her duties at least for a time. She has concluded to resign from the work. I advised her to put in an application for superannuation allowance, which I believe she has done.

Sir:

I beg to report as follows for the months of December and January:

X X X

DAY SCHOOLS.

Satisfactory reports have been received from all the day schools in the agency. Occasional complaints have been received from teachers regarding laxity in the attendance of some of the pupils. So far it has not been necessary to inflict penalties for truancy as provided in the Act though sometimes urged by teachers. I have always considered that better results could be obtained by teachers co-operating with the parents to ensure a better attendance.

I would draw to the Department's attention the fact that the junior class room of the Fort Simpson school is at present overcrowded, during the winter months when the people are back in the village the teacher has over fifty children of different grades to manage and has been compelled to divide up the work taking the junior grades in the mornings and the more advanced in the afternoons. This is not satisfactory on account of the comparatively short time the parents are resident in the village, and it is important that the children should have all the attention possible whilst they have the opportunity of attending school. I would therefore recommend that an extra teacher be obtained for this school next winter.

During my visit to Fort Simpson on December 20th, I was present at the closing exercises of the day school when a concert was put on by the pupils. Much credit is due to the teachers for the manner in which the pupils carried out their arts.

W. H. Collison,
Indian Agent.

The teacher of the junior class room, (Port Simpson), Miss Beamish, was being criticized by the local Missionaries who objected to her engaging in the organization of field sports amongst the half-breed people who live just outside the reserve while at the same time making no complaint as to her moral conduct and apparently manifesting no endeavour to do this kind of work themselves. The situation was discussed by Mr. Agent Collison and myself with Miss Beamish whose explanation seemed to us to be satisfactory. One of the sports affecting Miss Beamish was that she was seen in the school wood-shed in company with a half-breed named Begnon who had some time ago been ordered to keep away from the reserve. It was further alleged that one of the Nurses in training at Port Simpson Hospital was found to be pregnant as a result of familiarity with a half-breed Indian at Port Simpson. Seemingly these are the reasons for the opposition of the Missionaries to Miss Beamish and it seems probable that pressure will be exerted with a view to a change being made, although both Mr. Collison and I were impressed with the good intentions of this girl, who appeared keenly interested in clean sport and was anxious to exert her influence to this end in the community. Miss Beamish's work in the class-room is excellent and she has good discipline amongst the pupils.

C. C. Perry.

Dear Sir:

Re: Appointment of Teacher to Senior Room, Fort Simpson.

I have just arrived back in the office after six weeks in Western Canada and wish to thank you for your telegram addressed to me at Calgary and for your letter dated May 29th, approving the appointment of Miss Frances Patterson as Senior Teacher of the Port Simpson Day School. I am not satisfied, however, with the rate of salary which is allowed Miss Patterson. It seems strange that the Department should suggest the same salary for her, with her years of experience and her superior educational qualifications, as is being given to the Junior Teacher in the same school, who is under twenty years of age, has only a High School training, with Normal School certificate, and had no experience whatever when she went to Port Simpson. I sincerely hope that this rate may be revised so that Miss Patterson will be at least in receipt of $100.00 a month, less 10 per cent.

I should like to remind you that Miss Patterson's initial salary at Island Lake was $100.00 a month, in a school which is considerably less important from the standpoint of the Department of Indian Affairs than the one at Port Simpson, which during the last three or four years has been a difficult problem for the Agent and the Church, and everybody concerned.

Hoping that this request may have favorable consideration in spite of the limited budget under which the Department is laboring this year,

I am Yours very sincerely,

AGENT'S REPORT FOR THE MONTH OF MARCH 1939.

A report having been received that the day school at Fort Simpson had been broken into during the night of the 30th, I requested Constable Watkinson to proceed to the reserve and investigate the matter.

Although the identity of the culprit was not known there was a strong suspicion that the entry had been made by one of the older boys of the school. Nothing was stolen. This is the third time that the teacher's quarters have been entered presumably by older boys of the school.

I would again strongly recommend the appointment of a capable married man as teacher of the senior room who can handle the boys, and whose wife should be qualified to take charge of the junior classroom. Whilst the present lady teachers have given satisfactory service under conditions difficult at times, I am of the opinion that the senior class room should be under the supervision of a married teacher. In this arrangement, the same teacher's quarters would be utilized.

W. D. Collison,
Indian Agent.

PORT SIMPSON, B.C., Mar. 9/42.

To whom it may concern:

I have had Merlin Bunt, former principal of the Indian Day School at Port Simpson, under my care for the last seven weeks, four of which were spent in the hospital under active treatment.

The last week of January, being in a weakened condition, he took a very severe attack of Influenza with extreme prostration. This was followed by an attack of Septic Sore Throat and Broncho-pneumonia. Following a prolonged recovery he is much improved but not by any means in robust health. His course of disease reduced his weight by nearly twenty pounds and in every way took a good deal of vitality from him.

I have urged him to do nothing but recuperate for at least three months for I feel that at least this long is required for him to regain his former health.

It is on my advice that he has resigned his school position and I feel that any form of demanding work would be injurious for the next few months.

Yours very truly,

G.W. Fiddes, M.D., C.M.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Re - Fort Simpson Indian Day School
Your File 168-2-1

I have a further letter from Mr. Bunt to say that his son Merlin will not be in a fit state of health to return to Fort Simpson, and consequently we are asking that Mrs. Colwell continue to act as supply teacher until the end of the school year, which I presume is June 30th.

There ought to be no difficulty about filling this position when the time comes. I do, however, want to say, as I told you in Ottawa, that it is most difficult for the teachers to carry on when they have not only to teach the school and do all the work incidental thereto, but also to be responsible for attendance. I know perfectly well that legally they are not supposed to bother whether there is any attendance or not, but, unless they go to a great deal of trouble and have some concern about it, the attendance falls off. I wonder whether Mr. Gillett might be able to bring some pressure to bear on these people to send their children to school regularly. I presume he lives in Prince Rupert. I know of no man in the agency service who is more anxious to see progress made in education than Mr. Gillett, and consequently you will understand that, whilst I am asking that it be suggested that he bring some pressure to bear, it is by no means a criticism of his work in the past.

Yours sincerely,

GD.MLT

I acknowledge receipt of the Commissioner's letter 215-8-4974 with the copy of the school inspector's report.

The reason for only three pupils being present on the day of the inspector's visit was that the children had gone with their mothers to gather sea-weed. Mrs. Fogson, the teacher, stated that they were likely to be away for three or four days.

The attendance at this school had never been satisfactory. I brought this matter to the attention of the parents at a public meeting in January. It appears that the people of the village take their children with them to the logging-camps and other places of industry. The number that should attend at this school is twenty-four. Averages for the various months have been as follows:

| March     | 9.06    |
